(function () {\r\n            var hfSiteUrl = document.getElementById('hfSiteURL');\r\n            var siteUrl = hfSiteUrl.value;\r\n            var subdomainIndex = siteUrl.indexOf('/');\r\n\r\n $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \n    </div>\n    <div class=\"navbar-search-close js_close-navsearch\">Close</a>\r\n                    <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                        <div id=\"MicrositeSearch\" class=\"microsite-search\">\r\n                            <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter\"       </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input class=\"microsite-search-icon navbar-search-submit icon-menu_search\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search</span></a>\r\n\r\n                        </div>\r\n                    </div>                <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=74112271 id=\"74112271\" class=\"abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Strong gravitational lens systems with time delays between the multiple images allow measurements of time-delay distances, which are primarily sensitive to the Hubble constant that is key to probing dark energy, neutrino physics and the spatial curvature of the Universe, as well as discovering new physics. We present H0LiCOW (<em>H</em><sub>0</sub> Lenses in COSMOGRAIL's Wellspring), a program that aims to measure <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> with &lt;3.5\u2009per\u2009cent uncertainty from five lens systems (B1608+656, RXJ1131\u22121231, HE\u00a00435\u22121223, WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a01104\u22121805). We have been acquiring (1) time delays through COSMOGRAIL and Very Large Array monitoring, (2) high-resolution <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> imaging for the lens mass modelling, (3) wide-field imaging and spectroscopy to characterize the lens environment and (4) moderate-resolution spectroscopy to obtain the stellar velocity dispersion of the lenses for mass modelling. In cosmological models with one-parameter extension to flat \u039b cold dark matter, we expect to measure <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> to &lt;3.5\u2009per\u2009cent in most models, spatial curvature \u03a9<sub>k</sub> to 0.004, <em>w</em> to 0.14 and the effective number of neutrino species to 0.2 (1\u03c3 uncertainties) when combined with current cosmic microwave background (CMB) experiments. These are, respectively, a factor of \u223c15, \u223c2 and \u223c1.5 tighter than CMB alone. Our data set will further enable us to study the stellar initial mass function of the lens galaxies, and the co-evolution of supermassive black holes and their host galaxies. This program will provide a foundation for extracting cosmological distances from the hundreds of time-delay lenses that are expected to be discovered in current and future surveys.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;quasars: individual: B1608+656, RXJ1131\u22121231, HE\u00a00435\u22121223, WFI2033\u22124723, HE\u00a01104\u22121805&quot;\">quasars: individual: B1608+656, RXJ1131\u22121231, HE\u00a00435\u22121223, WFI2033\u22124723, HE\u00a01104\u22121805</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: structure&quot;\">galaxies: structure</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;cosmological parameters&quot;\">cosmological parameters</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;distance scale&quot;\">distance scale</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=74112273 id=\"74112273\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In the past decade, the so-called flat \u039b cold dark matter (\u039bCDM) cosmological model consisting of dark energy (with density characterized by a cosmological constant \u039b) and CDM in a spatially flat Universe has emerged as the standard cosmological model. This simple model has provided excellent fit to various cosmological observations including the temperature anisotropies in the cosmic microwave background (CMB) and galaxy density correlations in baryon acoustic oscillations (BAO). Recent CMB experiments, particularly the <em>Wilkinson Microwave Anisotropy Probe</em> (<em>WMAP</em>; Komatsu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib84\" data-open=\"bib84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Hinshaw et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) and the <em>Planck</em> satellite (Planck Collaboration XVI\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib119\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib119\" data-open=\"bib119\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Planck Collaboration XIII\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib120\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib120\" data-open=\"bib120\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), and BAO surveys (e.g. Anderson et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Kazin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Ross et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib131\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib131\" data-open=\"bib131\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), have yielded stringent constraints with unprecedented precision on cosmological parameters in the spatially flat \u039bCDM model.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">An interesting result from <em>Planck</em> is its predicted value of the Hubble constant (<em>H</em><sub>0</sub>), a key cosmological parameter that sets the present-day expansion rate as well as the age, size and critical density of the Universe. <em>Planck</em> does not directly measure <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>, but rather enables its indirect inference through measurements of combinations of cosmological parameters given assumptions of the background cosmological model. Intriguingly, <em>Planck</em>\u2019s value of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = 67.8 \u00b1 0.9\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u2212 1</sup> (Planck Collaboration XIII\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib120\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib120\" data-open=\"bib120\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), from <em>Planck</em> temperature data and <em>Planck</em> lensing under the flat \u039bCDM model, is lower than recent direct measurements based on the distance ladder, of 73.24 \u00b1 1.74\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u2212 1</sup> from the SH0ES program (Riess et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib128\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib128\" data-open=\"bib128\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) and of 74.3 \u00b1 2.1\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u2212 1</sup> (Freedman et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) from the Carnegie-Chicago Hubble Program (Beaton et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). On the other hand, <em>Planck</em>\u2019s <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> value is similar to the results of some of the megamaser measurements (e.g. <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = 68.9 \u00b1 7.1\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u2212 1</sup> from Reid et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib125\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib125\" data-open=\"bib125\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$H_0=73^{+26}_{-22}\\,\\rm km\\,s^{-1}\\,Mpc^{-1}$|</span> from Kuo et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib87\" data-open=\"bib87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a> and <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = 66.0 \u00b1 6.0\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u2212 1</sup> from Gao et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), although the uncertainties of these maser <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> measurements are still substantial relative to that of <em>Planck</em>. A 1\u00a0per\u00a0cent <em>direct</em> measurement of the Hubble constant is highly needed: such 1\u00a0per\u00a0cent measurements of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> would address the possible tension with the CMB value which, if significant, would point towards deviations from the standard flat \u039bCDM and new physics. In fact, when one relaxes, for example, the flatness or \u039b assumption in the CMB analysis, strong parameter degeneracies between <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> and other cosmological parameters appear, and the degenerate <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> values from the CMB become compatible with the local <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> measurements from the distance ladder (Freedman et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Planck Collaboration XIII\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib120\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib120\" data-open=\"bib120\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Riess et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib128\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib128\" data-open=\"bib128\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Thus, a 1\u00a0per\u00a0cent measurement of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> is crucial for understanding the nature of dark energy, neutrino physics, the spatial curvature of the Universe and the validity of General Relativity (e.g. Hu\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib158\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib158\" data-open=\"bib158\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>; Weinberg et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib182\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib182\" data-open=\"bib182\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). In particular, the dark energy figure of merit of any survey that does not directly measure <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> improves by \u223c40\u2009per\u2009cent if <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> is known to 1\u00a0per\u00a0cent. Furthermore, independent methods to measure <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> are necessary to overcome systematic effects, such as the known unknowns (e.g. the effects of crowding or metallicity dependence in the cosmic distance ladder) and the unknown unknowns in order to robustly verify or rule out the standard cosmological paradigm.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Strong gravitational lenses with measured time delays between the multiple images provide a competitive approach to measuring the Hubble constant, completely independent of the local distance ladder: we have demonstrated that we can constrain <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> to \u223c7\u20138\u2009per\u2009cent precision from a single time-delay lens system with ancillary data (Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib157\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib157\" data-open=\"bib157\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib161\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib161\" data-open=\"bib161\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). The time-delay method was first proposed by Refsdal (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib124\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib124\" data-open=\"bib124\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1964</a>) even before the discovery of the first strong gravitational lens system (Walsh, Carswell &amp; Weymann\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib180\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib180\" data-open=\"bib180\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1979</a>), consisting of a foreground mass distribution that is located close along the line of sight to a background source (see Treu &amp; Marshall\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib168\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib168\" data-open=\"bib168\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>, for a recent review). The light from the background source is deflected by the foreground \u2018lens\u2019 mass distribution; such light bending produces distorted and, in rare cases of \u2018strong lensing\u2019, multiple and often spectacular images of the background source (e.g. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"74112277\" scrollto-destination=\"74112277\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/468/3/10.1093_mnras_stx483/1/m_stx483fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611466631&amp;Signature=ag1Uz7eS61cDK~pm3x9pAxpymTcPDCNpkjyNUFA7iPykmQjoROvoEUXw0Jry4NMSXbKp1EF1vU~nDcvZEnkpQen8PFF8tEKdjHypcmCnsAXAV~D0ohwNlDegy0jlolzYf7DD29JhV1qRxpyOciWAkAxlRvkEiikqf~78WDA7nyTG6qzL3kb6hou0YanKa0VjGjq8JU1VRspMPh4WSoJX6FKFrpIDAPQ3iPhFTT625ISF9OQzvzFizajjihSglLsey-WZgBxqIMNRvg~39V79ni9aJkoo8Bsah4~BGI86MfLAVzp0z4pJz1Phc7UrTN5bUvL-ILSrz9-Va9K~P4u59g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"H0LiCOW lens sample, consisting of four quadruply lensed quasar systems in various configurations and one doubly lensed quasar system. The lens name is indicated above each panel. The colour images are composed using two (for B1608+656) or three (for other lenses) HST imaging bands in the optical and near-infrared. North is up and east is left.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx483fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/74112277/stx483fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx483fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"74112277\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/468/3/10.1093_mnras_stx483/1/stx483fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611466631&Signature=DIO8gvoiyTnJXo-I2LYkdeM4Py-koADOGEJVSPJVxZCwjAQ4wwIfwH-qWafAGXC2aZu50MT6V4iwky70Z4qXEjmqEMX78yC6QZbwOTi5RnVldIBU8YOlAXihtnD05GyslqMexnfJgBsjW4mcdHpRtsJfKzq5ehVM5dgHxJg0b-H-RBGw4XofYq5Bi6qaDdb8mLUbc7hBMTsYFBkytjY9NEOhTR1oNZUGemouehv4n9~iEwKmxHfztgz-kmb76vic4P~E8ltSJ1W~Yn0WGhnTblE~wpJz1uDuQTqSijYoKQpiVerEeoSSQ9~p0F11lVyi9Wh4zE2hQOS-oB6znUq~xg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=74112277&ar=3055701&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx483fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">H0LiCOW lens sample, consisting of four quadruply lensed quasar systems in various configurations and one doubly lensed quasar system. The lens name is indicated above each panel. The colour images are composed using two (for B1608+656) or three (for other lenses) <em>HST</em> imaging bands in the optical and near-infrared. North is up and east is left.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/468/3/10.1093_mnras_stx483/1/m_stx483fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611466631&amp;Signature=ag1Uz7eS61cDK~pm3x9pAxpymTcPDCNpkjyNUFA7iPykmQjoROvoEUXw0Jry4NMSXbKp1EF1vU~nDcvZEnkpQen8PFF8tEKdjHypcmCnsAXAV~D0ohwNlDegy0jlolzYf7DD29JhV1qRxpyOciWAkAxlRvkEiikqf~78WDA7nyTG6qzL3kb6hou0YanKa0VjGjq8JU1VRspMPh4WSoJX6FKFrpIDAPQ3iPhFTT625ISF9OQzvzFizajjihSglLsey-WZgBxqIMNRvg~39V79ni9aJkoo8Bsah4~BGI86MfLAVzp0z4pJz1Phc7UrTN5bUvL-ILSrz9-Va9K~P4u59g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"H0LiCOW lens sample, consisting of four quadruply lensed quasar systems in various configurations and one doubly lensed quasar system. The lens name is indicated above each panel. The colour images are composed using two (for B1608+656) or three (for other lenses) HST imaging bands in the optical and near-infrared. North is up and east is left.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx483fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/74112277/stx483fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx483fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"74112277\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/468/3/10.1093_mnras_stx483/1/stx483fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611466631&Signature=DIO8gvoiyTnJXo-I2LYkdeM4Py-koADOGEJVSPJVxZCwjAQ4wwIfwH-qWafAGXC2aZu50MT6V4iwky70Z4qXEjmqEMX78yC6QZbwOTi5RnVldIBU8YOlAXihtnD05GyslqMexnfJgBsjW4mcdHpRtsJfKzq5ehVM5dgHxJg0b-H-RBGw4XofYq5Bi6qaDdb8mLUbc7hBMTsYFBkytjY9NEOhTR1oNZUGemouehv4n9~iEwKmxHfztgz-kmb76vic4P~E8ltSJ1W~Yn0WGhnTblE~wpJz1uDuQTqSijYoKQpiVerEeoSSQ9~p0F11lVyi9Wh4zE2hQOS-oB6znUq~xg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=74112277&ar=3055701&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx483fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">H0LiCOW lens sample, consisting of four quadruply lensed quasar systems in various configurations and one doubly lensed quasar system. The lens name is indicated above each panel. The colour images are composed using two (for B1608+656) or three (for other lenses) <em>HST</em> imaging bands in the optical and near-infrared. North is up and east is left.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">When the background source is one that varies in its luminosity, such as an active galactic nucleus (AGN; e.g. Vanderriest et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib174\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib174\" data-open=\"bib174\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1989</a>; Schechter et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib135\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib135\" data-open=\"bib135\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>; Fassnacht et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Kochanek et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Courbin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) or a supernova (SN; e.g. Quimby et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib123\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib123\" data-open=\"bib123\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Kelly et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Goobar et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Grillo et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Kawamata et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; More et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib100\" data-open=\"bib100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016b</a>; Treu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib171\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib171\" data-open=\"bib171\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), the variability is manifest in each of the multiple images, but delayed in time relative to each other due to the different light paths. This time delay (\u0394<em>t</em>) thus depends on the \u2018time-delay distance\u2019 (<em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub>) and the lens mass distribution. Specifically, \u0394<em>t</em>\u00a0=\u00a0<em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub>\u0394\u03d5/<em>c</em>, where \u0394\u03d5 is the Fermat potential difference that is determined by the lens mass distribution and <em>c</em> is the speed of light. Therefore, by measuring the time delay from photometric light curves of the quasar images and modelling the lens mass distribution, one can determine the time-delay distance to the lens system and use the distance\u2013redshift relation to constrain cosmological models.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">More precisely, the time-delay distance is <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\nD_{\\Delta t}\\equiv (1+z_{\\rm d}) \\frac{D_{\\rm d}D_{\\rm s}}{D_{\\rm ds}}\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>(Refsdal\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib124\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib124\" data-open=\"bib124\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1964</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib157\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib157\" data-open=\"bib157\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), where <em>z</em><sub>d</sub> is the redshift of the foreground deflector (also referred to as the strong lens), <em>D</em><sub>d</sub> is the angular diameter distance to the deflector, <em>D</em><sub>s</sub> is the angular diameter distance to the source and <em>D</em><sub>ds</sub> is the angular diameter distance between the deflector and the source. This time-delay distance is for a single strong-lens plane, with other line-of-sight mass distributions only weakly perturbing the strong-lens system and characterized via external shear and convergence. For cases where there are massive line-of-sight mass distributions at a different redshift from the strong-lens galaxy yet close in projection to it such that these massive structures cannot be well approximated by an external shear/convergence, it is necessary to use the multiplane lensing formalism (e.g. Blandford &amp; Narayan\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1986</a>; Schneider, Ehlers &amp; Falco\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib138\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib138\" data-open=\"bib138\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1992</a>). In general, multilens plane ray tracing does not yield a single time-delay distance but rather several combinations of distances. None the less, even in some of these cases, we can derive an effective time-delay distance.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">As a result of the unique combination of these three angular diameter distances, the time-delay distance <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> is primarily sensitive to the Hubble constant, in contrast to other non-local distance probes such as SN that probe relative luminosity distances (e.g. Riess et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib127\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib127\" data-open=\"bib127\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>; Perlmutter et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib117\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib117\" data-open=\"bib117\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>; Conley et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Suzuki et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib163\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib163\" data-open=\"bib163\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Betoule et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) and BAO (e.g. Eisenstein et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; Percival et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib116\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib116\" data-open=\"bib116\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Blake et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Anderson et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) that yield absolute angular diameter distances. We note though that BAO, together with the CMB, can be used to calibrate the absolute magnitude of SN; assuming that the absolute magnitude of SN does not evolve with redshift, this combination of BAO and SN provides an \u2018inverse-distance ladder\u2019 for the Hubble constant that is insensitive to assumptions on dark energy properties and spatial curvature (e.g. Heavens, Jimenez &amp; Verde\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Aubourg et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). While BAO and the time-delay method both provide angular diameter distance measurements, the distinction is that BAO gives angular diameter distances at specific redshifts whereas the time-delay method yields time-delay distances (<em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub>) which are each a combination of three angular diameter distances. One could in fact determine the angular diameter distance to the lens <em>D</em><sub>d</sub> in addition to <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> for time-delay lenses that have stellar velocity dispersion measurements of the foreground lens galaxy (Paraficz &amp; Hjorth\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib113\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib113\" data-open=\"bib113\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Jee, Komatsu &amp; Suyu\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Without time delays, lenses with stellar velocity dispersion measurements can still offer a way to determine the cosmological matter and dark energy density parameters via a ratio of angular diameter distances (e.g. Futamase &amp; Hamana\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>; Futamase &amp; Yoshida\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>; Grillo, Lombardi &amp; Bertin\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). Recently, Jee et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) have shown that measurements of <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> and <em>D</em><sub>d</sub> from a modest sample of time-delay lenses with lens velocity dispersion measurements yield competitive constraints on cosmological models. In practice, both distances appear as intermediate quantities between the sought after cosmological parameters and the observed quantities.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to measure distances precisely and accurately from time-delay lenses, we need four key ingredients in addition to the spectroscopic redshifts of the lens and the source: (1) time delays, (2) high-resolution and high signal-to-noise ratio images of the lens systems, (3) characterization of the lens environment and (4) stellar velocity dispersion of the lens galaxy. These can be obtained via imaging and spectroscopy from <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) and ground-based observatories. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>, we detail each of these requirements.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We initiated the H0LiCOW (<em>H</em><sub>0</sub> Lenses in COSMOGRAIL's Wellspring) program with the aim of measuring the Hubble constant with better than 3.5\u2009per\u2009cent precision and accuracy (in most background cosmological models), through a sample of five time-delay lenses. We obtain the key ingredients to each of the lenses through observational follow-ups and novel analysis techniques. In particular, we have high-quality lensed quasar light curves, primarily obtained via optical monitoring by the COSMOGRAIL (COSmological MOnitoring of GRAvItational Lenses; e.g. Courbin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; Vuissoz et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib179\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib179\" data-open=\"bib179\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Courbin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Tewes et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib165\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib165\" data-open=\"bib165\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013b</a>) and Kochanek et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) teams but also via radio-wavelength monitoring (Fassnacht et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>). COSMOGRAIL has been monitoring more than 20 lensed quasars for more than a decade. The unprecedented quality of the light curves combined with new curve-shifting algorithms (Tewes, Courbin &amp; Meylan\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib164\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib164\" data-open=\"bib164\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013a</a>) lead to time delays with typically \u223c3\u00a0per\u00a0cent accuracy (Fassnacht et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Courbin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Tewes et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib165\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib165\" data-open=\"bib165\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013b</a>). In addition, we obtain <em>HST</em> imaging that reveal the \u2018Einstein ring\u2019 of the lens systems in high resolution, and develop state-of-the-art lens modelling techniques (Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib156\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib156\" data-open=\"bib156\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Suyu &amp; Halkola\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib155\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib155\" data-open=\"bib155\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib159\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib159\" data-open=\"bib159\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012b</a>) and kinematic modelling methods (Auger et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib147\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib147\" data-open=\"bib147\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) to obtain the lens mass distribution with a few percent uncertainty (e.g. Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib160\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib160\" data-open=\"bib160\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib161\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib161\" data-open=\"bib161\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). We further obtain wide-field imaging and spectroscopy to characterize the environment of the field, as well as the spectroscopy of the lens galaxy to obtain the stellar velocity dispersion. The exquisite follow-up data set that we have acquired allow us not only to constrain cosmology but also to study lens galaxy and source properties for understanding galaxy evolution, including the dark matter distribution in galaxies, the stellar initial mass function of galaxies and the co-evolution between supermassive black holes and their host galaxies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A crucial aspect of our program is the use of blind analysis (e.g. Conley et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Suzuki et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib163\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib163\" data-open=\"bib163\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib160\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib160\" data-open=\"bib160\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; von der Linden et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib177\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib177\" data-open=\"bib177\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) to test for residual systematics and avoid subconscious experimenter bias. In particular, we have developed core analysis techniques for the first lens whose dissection was not blinded (B1608+656; Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib157\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib157\" data-open=\"bib157\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>); we subsequently build upon these techniques and perform blind analysis on the other lenses in the sample. In the blind analysis, the idea is not to blind all the model parameters being inferred, but rather just the cosmological parameters that we aim to measure (as well as any derived parameters or summary statistics from which we could infer the cosmological parameters). We therefore blind the time-delay distance and all cosmological parameters in our analysis. Specifically, throughout the analysis, we only ever plot these blinded parameters offset by their posterior median value. We can then still use the parameter correlations and the uncertainties to cross check our analysis, since the temptation to stop investigating systematic errors when the \u2018right answer\u2019 has been obtained has been removed. Only when the collaboration deems the analysis to be final and complete do we \u2018open the box\u2019 to reveal the median values of the parameters, and then publish these results without modifications.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper (hereafter H0LiCOW Paper I) is the first of the series, and gives an overview of the program. There are four more papers that detail the data sets and analysis of the H0LiCOW lens system HE\u00a00435\u22121223. In particular, Sluse et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib144\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib144\" data-open=\"bib144\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>, hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib144\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib144\" data-open=\"bib144\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper II</a>) present the spectroscopic follow-up of the strong-lens field to measure redshifts of massive and nearby objects close in projection to the strong-lens system and identify galaxy groups along the line of sight. Rusu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib134\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib134\" data-open=\"bib134\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>, hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib134\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib134\" data-open=\"bib134\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper III</a>) use our multiband wide-field imaging to characterize the lens environment in combination with ray tracing with numerical simulations. Wong et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib187\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib187\" data-open=\"bib187\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>, hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib187\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib187\" data-open=\"bib187\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper IV</a>) perform the lens mass modelling of the strong-lens system incorporating the time delays, high-resolution imaging and lens stellar kinematics data sets to infer the distance to the lens via blind analysis. Bonvin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>, hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper V</a>) present the time-delay measurements from COSMOGRAIL lens monitoring and the cosmological inference based on the previous three papers.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The outline of this paper is as follows. We describe the key ingredients for time-delay cosmography in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>, present the five H0LiCOW lens systems in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a> and describe our observational campaign in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>. The key components of the four analysis papers introduced above are summarized in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>. We show the forecasted cosmographic constraints from the H0LiCOW sample in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6</a>. We summarize in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec7\"></span><a href=\"#sec7\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">7</a> with an outlook for the program.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=74112286 id=\"74112286\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 OBSERVATIONAL REQUIREMENTS OF THE TIME-DELAY METHOD</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we describe the observational requirements of the four ingredients for accurate and precise distance measurements from time-delay lenses. <ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Time delays</em>. Monitoring campaigns to map out the variability of the multiple lensed images over time have been carried out both in the radio and optical wavelengths (e.g. Vanderriest et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib174\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib174\" data-open=\"bib174\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1989</a>; Schechter et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib135\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib135\" data-open=\"bib135\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>; Burud et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Fassnacht et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Hjorth et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Kochanek et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Vuissoz et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib178\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib178\" data-open=\"bib178\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Rumbaugh et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib132\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib132\" data-open=\"bib132\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Regular and frequent observations, at least once every few days, are necessary so that the variability pattern of the background source can be observed in each of the multiple images and be matched up to obtain the time delays. Monitoring in the optical requires a long baseline or high photometric precision to overcome systematic variations due to microlensing by stars in the lensing galaxy that could be mistaken as the background source intrinsic variability (e.g. Tewes et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib165\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib165\" data-open=\"bib165\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013b</a>; Sluse &amp; Tewes\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib140\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib140\" data-open=\"bib140\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Curve-shifting methods have been developed to measure the time delays from the light curves (e.g. Press, Rybicki &amp; Hewitt\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib122\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib122\" data-open=\"bib122\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1992</a>; Pelt et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib114\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib114\" data-open=\"bib114\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; Fassnacht et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Harva &amp; Raychaudhury\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Morgan et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Hirv, Olspert &amp; Pelt\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Hojjati, Kim &amp; Linder\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Tewes, Courbin &amp; Meylan\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib164\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib164\" data-open=\"bib164\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013a</a>). A recent time-delay challenge showed that some of the methods can recover accurately the time delays in a blind test (Dobler et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Liao et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), particularly the methods we use from the COSMOGRAIL collaboration (e.g. Tewes et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib164\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib164\" data-open=\"bib164\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013a</a>; Bonvin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Well-resolved lensed images</em>. The strong-lensing information, such as the multiple image positions of the background source, is needed to obtain the foreground lens mass distribution for converting the time delays into distances. Deep and high-resolution imaging of the strong-lens system reveal the \u2018Einstein rings\u2019 that are the spatially extended and lensed images of the background source, such as the host galaxy of the AGN. In the past decade, methods have been developed to take advantage of the thousands of intensity pixels of the extended images to constrain precisely within a few percent the lens potential at the location of the multiple images (e.g. Kochanek, Keeton &amp; McLeod\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib82\" data-open=\"bib82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>; Warren &amp; Dye\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib181\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib181\" data-open=\"bib181\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Treu &amp; Koopmans\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib167\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib167\" data-open=\"bib167\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Koopmans\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; Dye et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib156\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib156\" data-open=\"bib156\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Vegetti &amp; Koopmans\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib175\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib175\" data-open=\"bib175\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib160\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib160\" data-open=\"bib160\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Birrer, Amara &amp; Refregier\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Chen et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). The time-delay distance is particularly sensitive to the radial profile of the lens galaxy mass distribution (e.g. Kochanek\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib81\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib81\" data-open=\"bib81\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Wucknitz\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib188\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib188\" data-open=\"bib188\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Wucknitz, Biggs &amp; Browne\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib189\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib189\" data-open=\"bib189\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Suyu\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib154\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib154\" data-open=\"bib154\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Imaging with high-signal-to-noise ratio and high angular resolution of the Einstein ring helps to constrain the lens radial profile in the region of the ring, and hence the time-delay distance, up to a mass-sheet transformation (described below).</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>The lens environment</em>. The distribution of mass external to the lens galaxy, such as that associated with galaxies which are close in projection to the lens system along the line of sight, affects the time delays between the multiple images and hence our cosmological distance measurements. An external convergence \u03ba<sub>ext</sub> can be absorbed by the lens and source model leaving the fit to the lensed images unchanged, but the predicted time delays altered by a factor of (1\u00a0\u2212\u00a0\u03ba<sub>ext</sub>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To break this \u2018mass-sheet degeneracy\u2019 (MSD; Falco, Gorenstein &amp; Shapiro <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1985</a>), one can study the environment of the lens system to constrain \u03ba<sub>ext</sub> within a few percent<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>1</sup></a> through spectroscopic/photometric observations of local galaxy groups and line-of-sight structures (e.g. Fassnacht et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Momcheva et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib97\" data-open=\"bib97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib98\" data-open=\"bib98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) in combination with ray tracing through numerical <em>N</em>-body simulations (e.g. Hilbert et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib157\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib157\" data-open=\"bib157\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Collett et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Greene et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Furthermore, McCully et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) developed a new framework to model line-of-sight mass distributions efficiently and quantified the environment effects through realistic simulations of lens fields. By reconstructing the three-dimensional mass distribution of strong-lens sightlines, McCully et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) can obtain constraints on \u03ba<sub>ext</sub> that are consistent with but tighter than those from the aforementioned statistical approach of combining galaxy number density observations with <em>N</em>-body simulations (see also Collett et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a> whose sightline mass reconstruction also produces tighter constraints on \u03ba<sub>ext</sub> than the statistical approach). Recently, Collett &amp; Cunnington (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) have pointed out that the external convergence over an ensemble of lenses usually does not average to zero \u2013 lenses, like typical massive galaxies, preferentially live in locally overdense regions (Holder &amp; Schechter\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib169\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib169\" data-open=\"bib169\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Fassnacht, Koopmans &amp; Wong <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and are therefore slightly easier to detect and monitor. None the less, this bias in detection and/or selection that is due to overdensity is expected to have currently negligible impact on <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> (&lt;1\u2009per\u2009cent impact). In contrast, measurements of <em>D</em><sub>d</sub> that come from combining delays with the lens velocity dispersion are impervious to \u03ba<sub>ext</sub> (Jee et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>The lens galaxy stellar velocity dispersion</em>. The combination of lensing and stellar kinematics is a powerful probe of the lens galaxy mass distribution (e.g. Romanowsky &amp; Kochanek\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib130\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib130\" data-open=\"bib130\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>; Treu &amp; Koopmans\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib166\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib166\" data-open=\"bib166\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Koopmans et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib86\" data-open=\"bib86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Barnab\u00e8 et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib147\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib147\" data-open=\"bib147\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) since the combination breaks degeneracies that are inherent in each approach, and in particular the mass-sheet degeneracy in lensing. Schneider &amp; Sluse (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib136\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib136\" data-open=\"bib136\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) pointed out that the mass-sheet degeneracy can manifest as a lens mass profile degeneracy, which Xu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib190\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib190\" data-open=\"bib190\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) investigated using simulated galaxies. Moreover, the mass-sheet degeneracy is in fact a special case of a more general \u2018source-position transformation\u2019 (Schneider &amp; Sluse\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib137\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib137\" data-open=\"bib137\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Unruh, Schneider &amp; Sluse\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib172\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib172\" data-open=\"bib172\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), although this latter transformation typically does not leave the multiple time delays invariant. To break such lensing degeneracies, information from the lens galaxy stellar kinematics is crucial: Suyu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib161\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib161\" data-open=\"bib161\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) showed that the lens velocity dispersion substantially reduced the dependence of the time-delay distance on lens mass profile assumptions. The lens velocity dispersion is also a key ingredient for measuring <em>D</em><sub>d</sub>, which is more sensitive to dark energy properties than <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> (Jee et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p></li></ul></p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=74112288 id=\"74112288\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 H0LICOW SAMPLE OF LENSES</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, we show the images of the five lenses in our sample. The left four lenses are quadruply lensed quasar systems (quads) and the rightmost lens system is a doubly lensed quasar system (double). As described below, the four quads span the three generic multiple image configurations we have in galaxy-scale strong lenses: symmetric, fold (with two merging images) and cusp (with three merging images). Therefore, our sample will allow us to explore to some extent the optimal image configuration for cosmographic studies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our sample of lenses was chosen based on three criteria: (1) availability of accurate and precise time delays, (2) existing measurements of spectroscopic redshifts for both the lens and the background source and (3) the lens system is not located near a galaxy cluster (to avoid potentially large systematic effects due to mass along the line of sight). We prefer quads to doubles since quads provide more observational constraints on the mass model (e.g. more time delays and image positions). The four quads in our sample were the only known quad lenses that passed the above three criteria at the time of our sample selection. There were a few doubles that pass these criteria, and we chose HE\u00a01104\u22121805 as the first double in this pilot program given its relative simplicity for mass modelling with only one strong-lens galaxy (in contrast to other systems that have multiple massive lens galaxies). We describe in more detail each of the lenses below.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>B1608+656</em>. The lens system was discovered in the Cosmic Lens All-Sky Survey (Myers et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1995</a>; Browne et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Myers et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>). The radio-loud AGN is lensed into four images that are relatively dim in the optical wavelength, thus showing clearly the extended Einstein ring of the AGN host galaxy in the <em>HST</em> imaging (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). Two of the four multiple images are close together, making this a standard \u2018fold\u2019 configuration. The system contains two lens galaxies that appear to be interacting and resulting in dust extinction in the system (e.g. Koopmans et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib86\" data-open=\"bib86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Surpi &amp; Blandford\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib153\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib153\" data-open=\"bib153\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib156\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib156\" data-open=\"bib156\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). The lens and source redshifts are, respectively, <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.394 (Fassnacht et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>) and <em>z</em><sub>d</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.6304 (Myers et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1995</a>). This system was the first quad lens with all three time delays measured with uncertainties of only a few percent (Fassnacht et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>RXJ1131\u22121231</em>. Sluse et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib141\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib141\" data-open=\"bib141\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) discovered RXJ1131\u22121231 serendipitously during polarimetric imaging of a sample of radio quasars. This system shows a spectacular Einstein ring, with multiple arclets that are the lensed images of the AGN host galaxy containing a bulge and a disk with spiral arms and star formation clumps. Three of the four quasar images are close to each other, forming the typical \u2018cusp\u2019 configuration. The lens redshift is at <em>z</em><sub>d</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.295 (Sluse et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib141\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib141\" data-open=\"bib141\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib142\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib142\" data-open=\"bib142\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>), and the source redshift is at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.654 (Sluse et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib142\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib142\" data-open=\"bib142\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>).<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>2</sup></a></p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>HE\u00a00435\u22121223</em>. This lens system was found by Wisotzki et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib186\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib186\" data-open=\"bib186\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>), originally selected in the Hamburg/ESO survey (Wisotzki et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib185\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib185\" data-open=\"bib185\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>) as a highly probable quasar candidate. The background quasar is lensed into four multiple images that are nearly symmetrically positioned in the \u2018cross\u2019 configuration. The background source is at redshift <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.693 (Sluse et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib143\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib143\" data-open=\"bib143\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>)<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>3</sup></a> and the foreground strong lens is at redshift <em>z</em><sub>d</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.4546 (Morgan et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib102\" data-open=\"bib102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; Eigenbrod et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). The <em>HST</em> image reveals an elliptical ring that connects the four images of the AGN. This ring is produced by the extended lensed images of the AGN galaxy.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>WFI2033\u22124723</em>. Morgan et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) discovered this quad lens system as part of an optical imaging survey using the MPG/ESO 2.2-m telescope at La Silla, Chile that is operated by the European Southern Observatory (ESO). The lens system exhibits a typical fold configuration, since it contains two merging quasar images. The quasar is at redshift <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.662 (Sluse et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib143\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib143\" data-open=\"bib143\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), which is consistent with the first measurement by Morgan et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>). The quasar images are substantially brighter than the background quasar host galaxy and the foreground lens galaxy. Morgan et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) identified the foreground lens galaxy, whose redshift was measured to be <em>z</em><sub>d</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.661 (Eigenbrod et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), consistent with an earlier measurement by Ofek et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib108\" data-open=\"bib108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). The high-resolution <em>HST</em> imaging shows several galaxies in the vicinity of the lens system. Since these galaxies would likely influence the lens potential, their redshifts will be obtained with our ancillary data (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.3</a>) in order to incorporate them into the lens mass model.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>HE\u00a01104\u22121805</em>. This system was also discovered in the early phase of the Hamburg/ESO survey by Wisotzki et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib184\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib184\" data-open=\"bib184\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1993</a>). The two lensed quasar images are separated by \u223c3<sup>\u2033</sup> and is unusual in having the brighter image as the one closer to the foreground lens galaxy, which was first identified by Courbin, Lidman &amp; Magain (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>) and Remy et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib126\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib126\" data-open=\"bib126\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>). The source is at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02.316 (Smette et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib145\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib145\" data-open=\"bib145\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1995</a>), and the lens is at a relatively high redshift of <em>z</em><sub>d</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.729 (Lidman et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib90\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib90\" data-open=\"bib90\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>). The <em>HST</em> image shows multiple luminous structures/galaxies around the lens system.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=74112296 id=\"74112296\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 OBSERVATIONAL FOLLOW-UP</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In collaboration with the COSMOGRAIL team, we carry out an observational campaign in order to obtain each of the four ingredients for distance measurements of the H0LiCOW lenses. We describe the monitoring in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.1</a> to get the time delays, deep <em>HST</em> imaging to constrain the lens galaxy mass distribution in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.2</a>, wide-field spectroscopy and imaging to study the lens environment in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.3</a> and spectroscopy of the foreground lens galaxy to measure the stellar velocity dispersion in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.4</a>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=74112298 id=\"74112298\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 Time delays</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Of the five H0LiCOW lenses, B1608+656 has been monitored previously by Fassnacht et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>) using the Very Large Array, whereas the other four lenses are currently being monitored by the COSMOGRAIL and Kochanek et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) collaborations using a network of 1\u20132\u00a0m optical telescopes, particularly the Euler telescope in Chile.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Using three seasons of monitoring of B1608+656, especially the third season that showed significant variability that repeated in all four quasar images, Fassnacht et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>) measured all three relative time delays between the four quasar images with uncertainties of a few percent. The image fluxes were measured every 3\u20134\u00a0d during the monitoring. The time delays span \u223c30\u201380\u00a0d, relative to the first image that varies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The monitoring of RXJ1131\u22121231, HE\u00a00435\u22121223, WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a01104\u22121805 by the COSMOGRAIL and Kochanek et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) teams started in 2003, with a photometric point every 2\u20134\u00a0d. The MCS deconvolution method (Magain, Courbin &amp; Sohy\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib94\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib94\" data-open=\"bib94\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>; Cantale et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) is used to extract the photometry of the quasar images for building the light curves. Tewes et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib164\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib164\" data-open=\"bib164\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013a</a>) set up an automated pipeline to reduce the images, build the light curves and measure the time delays using a state-of-the-art curve-shifting algorithm that simultaneously models both intrinsic variability of the AGNs and microlensing variations. With this pipeline, Bonvin et\u00a0al.
