(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) recovered the time delays with a precision of \u223c3\u2009per\u2009cent and negligible bias for simulated light curves mimicking COSMOGRAIL monitoring in the blind strong-lens time delay challenge (Liao et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), demonstrating the robustness of their curve-shifting algorithms.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The monitoring and analysis yield time delays in RXJ1131\u22121231 with a 1.5\u2009per\u2009cent uncertainty on the longest delay (Tewes et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib165\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib165\" data-open=\"bib165\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013b</a>). The light curve has been separately modelled by A. Hojjati and E. Linder using the Gaussian process technique (Hojjati et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), who have obtained delays that are consistent with the measurements of Tewes et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib165\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib165\" data-open=\"bib165\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013b</a>) (Linder, private communication). The monitoring and analysis of HE\u00a00435\u22121223 are described in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper V</a>, with a relative uncertainty of 6.5\u2009per\u2009cent on the longest delay (between images A and D). The measurement precision in the delays has improved by a factor of 2 compared to the previous measurements by Courbin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) with the five additional years of monitoring and improvements in the curve-shifting algorithms. For WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a01104\u22121805, we expect to improve on the previous delay measurements by Vuissoz et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib179\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib179\" data-open=\"bib179\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>) and Poindexter et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib121\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib121\" data-open=\"bib121\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>), respectively, with the new curve-shifting techniques, and estimate relative uncertainties of \u223c4\u2009per\u2009cent and \u223c2\u2009per\u2009cent, respectively, from the monitoring campaign.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=74112303 id=\"74112303\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>4.2 <em>HST</em> observations</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Deep <em>HST</em> Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS) observations of B1608+656 were obtained in Program 10158 (PI: C. D. Fassnacht) in two filters, <em>F</em>606<em>W</em> and <em>F</em>814<em>W</em>. Suyu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib156\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib156\" data-open=\"bib156\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) have described these observations in detail. Furthermore, Suyu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib156\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib156\" data-open=\"bib156\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) analysed these data and used a pixelated lens potential reconstruction technique to model the lens mass distribution, which were subsequently used for cosmographic analysis in Suyu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib157\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib157\" data-open=\"bib157\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Archival <em>HST</em> ACS observations of RXJ1131\u22121231 (Program 9744; PI: C. S. Kochanek) are available in two filters, <em>F</em>555<em>W</em> and <em>F</em>814<em>W</em>. Details of the observations are described in, e.g. Claeskens et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). These have been used to model the lens mass distribution for cosmography, accounting for uncertainties due to assumptions on the lens mass profile (Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib160\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib160\" data-open=\"bib160\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib161\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib161\" data-open=\"bib161\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Recently, Birrer, Amara &amp; Refregier (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) have also used these observations to model independently the lens mass distribution of RXJ1131\u22121231 for cosmography, obtaining results that are consistent with Suyu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib160\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib160\" data-open=\"bib160\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We have obtained new deep <em>HST</em> Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3) observations in Program 12889 (PI: S. H. Suyu) of the remaining three lenses (HE\u00a00435\u22121223, WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a01104\u22121805) in the infrared (IR) channel. The goal of these observations is to detect the Einstein rings of the AGN host galaxies at high signal-to-noise ratios, in order to constrain the foreground lens mass distribution (previous <em>HST</em> observations had insufficient signal-to-noise ratios of the rings for our analysis). We use the <em>F</em>160<em>W</em> filter to optimize the contrast between the AGN host galaxy and the AGN, since the host galaxy is brighter in the IR compared to the optical, especially for HE\u00a01104\u22121805 where the quasar is at a high redshift.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We employ four-point dither patterns that trace out parallelograms with the lengths of the sides being non-integral numbers of pixels. For each lens, we use multiple parallelograms that are offset by non-integral pixels. Specifically, we use 2, 5 and 3 parallelograms for HE\u00a00435\u22121223, WFI2033\u22124723and HE\u00a01104\u22121805, respectively, depending on the total exposure time needed to image the Einstein ring. We further ensure that the dithering points do not overlap to avoid IR persistence effects. This dithering strategy allows us to recover effectively an angular resolution of \u223c0.08arcsec from the native 0.13\u00a0arcsec\u00a0pixel scale.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Since the AGN host galaxy is substantially fainter than the AGN, we further adopt an exposure sequence of short\u2013long\u2013long at each of the dithering point.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>4</sup></a> The first short exposure allows us to characterize the AGN, whereas the long exposures would get the AGN host with possibly the pixels near the bright AGN saturated. We note that there are multiple non-destructive reads during each exposure with the MULTIACCUM mode of the WFC3/IR detector, so we can have a count rate estimate on the AGN pixels even in the long exposures if several non-destructive reads are available before saturation. The short exposures are taken to ensure that there are sufficient reads to characterize accurately the pixel count rates near the AGN positions, in case the long exposures are indeed saturated with insufficient non-destructive reads. In essence, the combination of the short and long exposures allows us to reconstruct in full the brightness distribution of <em>both</em> the lensed AGN and the lensed host galaxy. We summarize our observations in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"74112309\" scrollto-destination=\"74112309\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap short exp.\u00a0</td><td>74\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>to 2013-05-04\u00a0</td><td>4 long exp.<sup>4</sup>\u00a0</td><td>599\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>32 long exp.<sup>4</sup>\u00a0</td><td>699\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HE\u00a01104\u22121805\u00a0</td><td>2013-03-18\u00a0</td><td>12 short exp.\u00a0</td><td>26\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>24 long exp.\u00a0</td><td>599\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span At each dither position, an exposure sequence of short\u2013long\u2013long exposure times is adopted in order to sample the large dynamical range of the AGN and its much fainter host galaxy.<sup>4</sup></p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/74112309\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">New <em>HST</em> WFC3/IR Observations of HE\u00a00435\u22121223, WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a01104\u22121805.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Lens<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Date<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Number/type<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Time (s) per<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>of exposures<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>exposure<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>HE\u00a00435\u22121223\u00a0</td><td>2012-10-28\u00a0</td><td>8 short exp.\u00a0</td><td>44\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>15 long exp.<sup>4</sup>\u00a0</td><td>599\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WFI2033\u22124723\u00a0</td><td>2013-05-03\u00a0</td><td>20 short exp.\u00a0</td><td>74\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>to 2013-05-04\u00a0</td><td>4 long exp.<sup>4</sup>\u00a0</td><td>599\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>32 long exp.<sup>4</sup>\u00a0</td><td>699\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HE\u00a01104\u22121805\u00a0</td><td>2013-03-18\u00a0</td><td>12 short exp.\u00a0</td><td>26\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>24 long exp.\u00a0</td><td>599\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Lens<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Date<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Number/type<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Time (s) per<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>of exposures<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>exposure<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>HE\u00a00435\u22121223\u00a0</td><td>2012-10-28\u00a0</td><td>8 short exp.\u00a0</td><td>44\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>15 long exp.<sup>4</sup>\u00a0</td><td>599\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WFI2033\u22124723\u00a0</td><td>2013-05-03\u00a0</td><td>20 short exp.\u00a0</td><td>74\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>to 2013-05-04\u00a0</td><td>4 long exp.<sup>4</sup>\u00a0</td><td>599\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>32 long exp.<sup>4</sup>\u00a0</td><td>699\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HE\u00a01104\u22121805\u00a0</td><td>2013-03-18\u00a0</td><td>12 short exp.\u00a0</td><td>26\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>24 long exp.\u00a0</td><td>599\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN001\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN001\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>. At each dither position, an exposure sequence of short\u2013long\u2013long exposure times is adopted in order to sample the large dynamical range of the AGN and its much fainter host galaxy.<sup>4</sup></p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/74112309\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We reduce the images using <span class=\"small-caps\">DrizzlePac</span>.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn5\" data-open=\"fn5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>5</sup></a> The images are drizzled to a final pixel scale of 0.08 arcsec, without masking the bright AGN pixels as they are well characterized by the short exposures. The uncertainty on the flux in each pixel is estimated from the science image and the drizzled exposure time map by adding in quadrature the Poisson noise from the source and the background noise due to the sky and detector readout.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, we show the reduced <em>HST</em> WFC3 observations of HE\u00a00435\u22121223, WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a00435\u22121223 in the top panels from left to right. In the bottom, we show the images with the lens light subtracted with <span class=\"small-caps\">glee</span>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn6\" data-open=\"fn6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>6</sup></a> revealing the Einstein ring of the AGN host galaxy. In <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib187\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib187\" data-open=\"bib187\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper IV</a>, we detail the modelling of HE\u00a00435\u22121223 using multilens-plane ray tracing (e.g. Blandford &amp; Narayan\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1986</a>; Schneider et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib138\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib138\" data-open=\"bib138\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1992</a>; Blandford &amp; Kochanek\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) and point spread function (PSF) reconstruction techniques developed by Suyu et\u00a0al. (in preparation). The subtraction of lens light in WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a01104\u22121805 (bottom-middle and bottom-right panels of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, respectively) is based on an initial PSF built from stars in the field without any lens mass modelling or iterative PSF reconstruction, hence the lens-subtraction residuals. Furthermore, the lens galaxy of HE\u00a01104\u22121805 is on a diffraction spike of the brighter AGN image \u2013 an accurate PSF model would be crucial for distinguishing the lens galaxy, the two AGN images and the lensed host galaxy of the AGN. The full modelling and analysis of WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a01104\u22121805 will appear in future publications.</p>                        <a id=\"74112312\" scrollto-destination=\"74112312\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/468/3/10.1093_mnras_stx483/1/m_stx483fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611466631&amp;Signature=vcQX7HAyabEEYj2B4bJgylkjUxDfa7E0FOPRg9O259UROajboXWPYlGoegN7tJmONoF4nEOSs-6iWJEl5EHjU-gHu4T65aSDKuh0wpQimAkDyW5kosdXz-c4a4KrbZlzw-843Ncaog~5JPN29KB9jTr2-PlLqwgO4HW6~E9sKJXgFAoG0spA4Ot15gN1ydvvx4RPK2tlkwMLCNMBTR8B~OeBeFbBPAZErgeympbfvL1ZOnsl6r1HC7AFsQw2rD2WECFZnzXAzFRIfwD0SedAzF1lfZFkGzS6jjG7we1-ptdntJWK6SWL3~dQPGJGUIxof~bQF3tFruM9it3bB-el3A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"HST WFC3 F160W observation of HE\u00a00435\u22121223, WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a01104\u22121805 from left to right in the top panels. In the bottom panels, the lens-galaxy light has been subtracted, revealing the Einstein ring of the AGN host galaxy that is needed for accurate and precise lens mass modelling. The full modelling of HE\u00a00435\u22121223 is detailed in H0LiCOW Paper IV. The lens subtraction for WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a01104\u22121805 in the bottom-middle and bottom-right panels, respectively, is based on an initial PSF model without PSF reconstruction (which we defer to future work), hence the visible residuals. In each of the panels, north is up and east is left.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/468/3/10.1093_mnras_stx483/1/m_stx483fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611466631&amp;Signature=vcQX7HAyabEEYj2B4bJgylkjUxDfa7E0FOPRg9O259UROajboXWPYlGoegN7tJmONoF4nEOSs-6iWJEl5EHjU-gHu4T65aSDKuh0wpQimAkDyW5kosdXz-c4a4KrbZlzw-843Ncaog~5JPN29KB9jTr2-PlLqwgO4HW6~E9sKJXgFAoG0spA4Ot15gN1ydvvx4RPK2tlkwMLCNMBTR8B~OeBeFbBPAZErgeympbfvL1ZOnsl6r1HC7AFsQw2rD2WECFZnzXAzFRIfwD0SedAzF1lfZFkGzS6jjG7we1-ptdntJWK6SWL3~dQPGJGUIxof~bQF3tFruM9it3bB-el3A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"HST WFC3 F160W observation of HE\u00a00435\u22121223, WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a01104\u22121805 from left to right in the top panels. In each of the panels, north is up and east is left.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx483fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/74112312/stx483fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx483fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"74112312\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/468/3/10.1093_mnras_stx483/1/stx483fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611466631&Signature=EW9bYdGwq~YXUDo28DbhdwSitvpuu-G~9YYiwGqIwvhd04leoIOuO38ka5QENVq6Z-jC~Emb7xBeUjfR6mcHvJ~RoTSxYkyceKx~grKCtAzBq8qc1OSPLh6N1UFv3EGxTJFx0inHwr1aOAiN7xRqq63whjF06-vi7jIV3xGaYuJaytZlhu9JL2M3TpkB3KaKZSmcgoyJd71-lHCCXGDrVFQ1vu2tB4GegUgsMYocH4h02xamTJ7ha28iJRCjijvFGMu371RVop7Mt4jKx8PAFskxDPuAKg5YesPuqGuJ6IuGYCPuHyV6aqkMejngFzI2ot9MnxN~-0IDIZhJ6JbNuQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=74112312&ar=3055701&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx483fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>HST</em> WFC3 <em>F</em>160<em>W</em> observation of HE\u00a00435\u22121223, WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a01104\u22121805 from left to right in the top panels. In the bottom panels, the lens-galaxy light has been subtracted, revealing the Einstein ring of the AGN host galaxy that is needed for accurate and precise lens mass modelling. The full modelling of HE\u00a00435\u22121223 is detailed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib187\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib187\" data-open=\"bib187\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper IV</a>. The lens subtraction for WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a01104\u22121805 in the bottom-middle and bottom-right panels, respectively, is based on an initial PSF model without PSF reconstruction (which we defer to future work), hence the visible residuals. In each of the panels, north is up and east is left.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=74112313 id=\"74112313\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3>4.3 Wide-field spectroscopy and imaging of lens environment</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We obtain wide-field spectroscopy to pinpoint the redshifts of the bright galaxies in the fields of the H0LiCOW lenses, particularly the ones close to the strong lens. Redshifts of nearby galaxies, especially those within a few arcseconds from the strong lens, are crucial since the external convergence approximation is often insufficient for these galaxies (e.g. McCully et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) and they need to be incorporated directly into the strong-lens modelling. We use the multiobject spectrographs on the Very Large Telescope, the Gemini Telescope and the W. M. Keck Telescope to target our lens fields, as summarized in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. The spectroscopic redshifts and galaxy group identifications are detailed in Fassnacht et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib144\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib144\" data-open=\"bib144\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper II</a>, and forthcoming publications.</p>                        <a id=\"74112315\" scrollto-destination=\"74112315\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Wide-field spectroscopy of H0LiCOW lenses as part of the H0LiCOW program.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Lens<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Facility/instrument<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Proposal PI<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>B1608+656\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/LRIS\u00a0</td><td>C. D. Fassnacht\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/ESI\u00a0</td><td>C. D. Fassnacht\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>RXJ1131\u22121231\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/LRIS\u00a0</td><td>C. D. Fassnacht\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HE\u00a00435\u22121223\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/LRIS\u00a0</td><td>C. D. M. Keck/LRIS\u00a0</td><td>C. D. Fassnacht\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/ESI\u00a0</td><td>C. D. Fassnacht\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>RXJ1131\u22121231\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Treu\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN002\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN002\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>. Abbreviations are LRIS (Low-Resolution Imaging Spectrometer; Oke et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib112\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib112\" data-open=\"bib112\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1995</a>; Rockosi et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib129\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib129\" data-open=\"bib129\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), ESI (Echellete Spectrograph and Imager; Sheinis et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib139\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib139\" data-open=\"bib139\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>), VLT (Very Large Telescope), FORS2 (FOcal Reducer and low dispersion Spectrograph; Appenzeller et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>) and GMOS (Gemini Multi-Object Spectrographs; Hook et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>). Details of the observations for B1608+656 are in Fassnacht et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), and for the other four lenses are in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib144\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib144\" data-open=\"bib144\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper II</a> and forthcoming publications. Additional integral field spectroscopy of the central 30 arcmin around WFI2033\u22124723 has been recently obtained with the Multi Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE; Bacon et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) on the VLT.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/74112315\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Wide-field spectroscopy of H0LiCOW lenses as part of the H0LiCOW program.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Lens<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Facility/instrument<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Proposal PI<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>B1608+656\u00a0</td><td>W. Abbreviations are LRIS (Low-Resolution Imaging Spectrometer; Oke et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib112\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib112\" data-open=\"bib112\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1995</a>; Rockosi et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib129\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib129\" data-open=\"bib129\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), ESI (Echellete Spectrograph and Imager; Sheinis et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib139\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib139\" data-open=\"bib139\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>), VLT (Very Large Telescope), FORS2 (FOcal Reducer and low dispersion Spectrograph; Appenzeller et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>) and GMOS (Gemini Multi-Object Spectrographs; Hook et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>). Details of the observations for B1608+656 are in Fassnacht et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), and for the other four lenses are in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib144\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib144\" data-open=\"bib144\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper II</a> and forthcoming publications. Additional integral field spectroscopy of the central 30 arcmin around WFI2033\u22124723 has been recently obtained with the Multi Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE; Bacon et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) on the VLT.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/74112315\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">To further characterize the lens environment and determine \u03ba<sub>ext</sub>, we obtain wide-field multiband imaging using the Canada\u2013France\u2013Hawaii Telescope, Subaru Telescope, the Very Large Telescope, Gemini Telescope and <em>Spitzer Space Telescope</em>. Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> summarizes the follow-up imaging that allow us to compute the photometric redshifts of structures along the line of sight as well as to estimate their stellar masses. Details of the observations and inference on \u03ba<sub>ext</sub> are described in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib134\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib134\" data-open=\"bib134\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper III</a> and forthcoming publications.</p>                        <a id=\"74112317\" scrollto-destination=\"74112317\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl3\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Wide-field imaging obtained as part of the H0LiCOW program.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Lens<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Facility/instrument<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Wavelength bands<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Proposal PI<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>B1608+656\u00a0</td><td>CFHT/MegaCam\u00a0</td><td><em>u</em>\u00a0</td><td>S. Abbreviations and references for the instruments are CFHT (Canada\u2013France\u2013Hawaii Telescope) MegaCam (Boulade et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>), Suprime-Cam (Miyazaki et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib96\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib96\" data-open=\"bib96\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>), MOIRCS (Multi-Object InfraRed Camera and Spectrograph; Suzuki et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib162\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib162\" data-open=\"bib162\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Ichikawa et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), NIRI (Near InfraRed Imager and Spectrometer; Hodapp et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>), IRAC (Infrared Array Camera; Fazio et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>), CTIO (Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory) DECam (Dark Energy Camera; Diehl &amp; Dark Energy Survey Collaboration\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), VLT (Very Large Telescope) HAWK-I (High Acuity Wide field K-band Imager; Pirard et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib118\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib118\" data-open=\"bib118\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Casali et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Kissler-Patig et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). Details of the observations are in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib134\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib134\" data-open=\"bib134\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper III</a> and forthcoming publications. WFI2033\u22124723 is in the footprint of the Dark Energy Survey with observations in <em>g</em>, <em>r</em>, <em>i</em>, <em>z</em> and <em>Y</em> bands, so we did not target WFI2033\u22124723 in these bands. We observed only B1608+656 with <em>Spitzer</em> since the other four lenses have archival <em>Spitzer</em>/IRAC observations (PI: C. S. Kochanek).</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/74112317\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Wide-field imaging obtained as part of the H0LiCOW program.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Lens<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Facility/instrument<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Wavelength bands<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Proposal PI<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>B1608+656\u00a0</td><td>CFHT/MegaCam\u00a0</td><td><em>u</em>\u00a0</td><td>S. Abbreviations and references for the instruments are CFHT (Canada\u2013France\u2013Hawaii Telescope) MegaCam (Boulade et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>), Suprime-Cam (Miyazaki et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib96\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib96\" data-open=\"bib96\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>), MOIRCS (Multi-Object InfraRed Camera and Spectrograph; Suzuki et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib162\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib162\" data-open=\"bib162\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Ichikawa et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), NIRI (Near InfraRed Imager and Spectrometer; Hodapp et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>), IRAC (Infrared Array Camera; Fazio et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>), CTIO (Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory) DECam (Dark Energy Camera; Diehl &amp; Dark Energy Survey Collaboration\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), VLT (Very Large Telescope) HAWK-I (High Acuity Wide field K-band Imager; Pirard et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib118\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib118\" data-open=\"bib118\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Casali et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Kissler-Patig et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). Details of the observations are in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib134\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib134\" data-open=\"bib134\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper III</a> and forthcoming publications. WFI2033\u22124723 is in the footprint of the Dark Energy Survey with observations in <em>g</em>, <em>r</em>, <em>i</em>, <em>z</em> and <em>Y</em> bands, so we did not target WFI2033\u22124723 in these bands. We observed only B1608+656 with <em>Spitzer</em> since the other four lenses have archival <em>Spitzer</em>/IRAC observations (PI: C. S. Kochanek).</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/74112317\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Williams et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib183\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib183\" data-open=\"bib183\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) have independently obtained <em>I</em> and either <em>V</em> or <em>R</em> images of all five H0LiCOW lenses using the 4-m Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory (CTIO) Blanco telescope for the southern fields and the 4-m Kitt Peak National Observatory Mayall telescope for the northern fields. Using these images to select spectroscopic targets, Momcheva et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib98\" data-open=\"bib98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) have obtained spectroscopic observations of the five H0LiCOW lenses using the 6.5-m Magellan telescopes. In <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib144\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib144\" data-open=\"bib144\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper II</a>, we merge the spectroscopic catalogue from the multiple spectroscopic campaigns on HE\u00a00435\u22121223.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=74112319 id=\"74112319\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-4>4.4 Lens galaxy spectroscopy for lens velocity dispersion</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">For B1608+656 and RXJ1131\u22121231, we have obtained long-slit spectra of the lens systems with the Low-Resolution Imaging Spectrometer (LRIS; Oke et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib112\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib112\" data-open=\"bib112\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1995</a>) at the Keck Observatory for measuring the lens stellar velocity dispersion (Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib157\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib157\" data-open=\"bib157\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib160\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib160\" data-open=\"bib160\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). For HE\u00a00435\u22121223, we observe the lens system with LRIS in multiobject mode to obtain spectra of the foreground lens galaxy for lens velocity dispersion measurement (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib187\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib187\" data-open=\"bib187\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper IV</a>) and also of nearby galaxies (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib144\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib144\" data-open=\"bib144\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper II</a>). Both WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a01104\u22121805 have bright AGNs relative to the lens galaxy, making the lens velocity dispersion measurement challenging. We have new observations of WFI2033\u22124723 with MUSE (Bacon et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) at the VLT, which we expect will allow us to reduce the uncertainty on the current lens velocity dispersion by a factor of 2, to \u223c5\u20137\u2009per\u2009cent precision. The velocity dispersion is a key ingredient to break the MSD/lensing degeneracies (e.g. Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib161\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib161\" data-open=\"bib161\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). For HE\u00a01104\u22121805, we obtained one-sixth of our proposed observations with XSHOOTER on the VLT in priority B, which is not sufficient to measure the velocity dispersion. We have time on OSIRIS (OH-Suppressing Infra-Red Imaging Spectrograph; Larkin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) on Keck to observe HE\u00a01104\u22121805, RXJ1131\u22121231and HE\u00a00435\u22121223 with adaptive optics. Because OSIRIS is an integral field spectrograph, these observations have the goal of obtaining two-dimensional kinematic data of the foreground lens, which will then be used to further constrain the lens mass models. We summarize the spectroscopic observations for lens velocity dispersion measurement in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"74112321\" scrollto-destination=\"74112321\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl4\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl4\" data-id=\"tbl4\"><span class=\"label\">Table 4.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Spectroscopy of foreground lens as part of the H0LiCOW program.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Lens<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Facility/instrument<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Proposal PI<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>B1608+656\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/LRIS\u00a0</td><td>C. D. Fassnacht\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>RXJ1131\u22121231\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/LRIS\u00a0</td><td>C. D. Fassnacht\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/OSIRIS\u00a0</td><td>T. Treu\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HE\u00a00435\u22121223\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/LRIS\u00a0</td><td>C. D. Fassnacht\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/OSIRIS\u00a0</td><td>T. Treu\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WFI2033\u22124723\u00a0</td><td>VLT/MUSE\u00a0</td><td>D. Sluse\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HE\u00a01104\u22121805\u00a0</td><td>VLT/X-shooter\u00a0</td><td>C. Spiniello\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/OSIRIS\u00a0</td><td>T. Treu\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Lens<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Facility/instrument<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Proposal PI<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>B1608+656\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/LRIS\u00a0</td><td>C. D. Fassnacht\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>RXJ1131\u22121231\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/LRIS\u00a0</td><td>C. D. Fassnacht\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/OSIRIS\u00a0</td><td>T. Treu\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HE\u00a00435\u22121223\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/LRIS\u00a0</td><td>C. D. Fassnacht\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/OSIRIS\u00a0</td><td>T. Treu\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WFI2033\u22124723\u00a0</td><td>VLT/MUSE\u00a0</td><td>D. Sluse\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HE\u00a01104\u22121805\u00a0</td><td>VLT/X-shooter\u00a0</td><td>C. Spiniello\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/OSIRIS\u00a0</td><td>T. Treu\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN004\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN004\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>. OSIRIS is the OH-Suppressing Infra-Red Imaging Spectrograph (Larkin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). Details of the LRIS observations for B1608+656 are in Suyu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib157\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib157\" data-open=\"bib157\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), for RXJ1131\u22121231 are in Suyu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib160\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib160\" data-open=\"bib160\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), and for HE\u00a00435\u22121223 are in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib187\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib187\" data-open=\"bib187\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper IV</a>; other observations are in forthcoming publications. Only one-sixth of the HE\u00a01104\u22121805 observations with X-shooter (Vernet et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib176\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib176\" data-open=\"bib176\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) were obtained, which were insufficient for measuring the lens velocity dispersion. The observations with OSIRIS are pending.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/74112321\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl4\" data-id=\"tbl4\"><span class=\"label\">Table 4.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Spectroscopy of foreground lens as part of the H0LiCOW program.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Lens<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Facility/instrument<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Proposal PI<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>B1608+656\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/LRIS\u00a0</td><td>C. D. Fassnacht\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>RXJ1131\u22121231\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/LRIS\u00a0</td><td>C. D. Fassnacht\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/OSIRIS\u00a0</td><td>T. Treu\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HE\u00a00435\u22121223\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/LRIS\u00a0</td><td>C. D. Fassnacht\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/OSIRIS\u00a0</td><td>T. Treu\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WFI2033\u22124723\u00a0</td><td>VLT/MUSE\u00a0</td><td>D. Sluse\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HE\u00a01104\u22121805\u00a0</td><td>VLT/X-shooter\u00a0</td><td>C. Spiniello\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/OSIRIS\u00a0</td><td>T. Treu\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Lens<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Facility/instrument<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Proposal PI<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>B1608+656\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/LRIS\u00a0</td><td>C. D. Fassnacht\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>RXJ1131\u22121231\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/LRIS\u00a0</td><td>C. D. Fassnacht\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/OSIRIS\u00a0</td><td>T. Treu\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HE\u00a00435\u22121223\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/LRIS\u00a0</td><td>C. D. Fassnacht\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/OSIRIS\u00a0</td><td>T. Treu\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WFI2033\u22124723\u00a0</td><td>VLT/MUSE\u00a0</td><td>D. Sluse\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HE\u00a01104\u22121805\u00a0</td><td>VLT/X-shooter\u00a0</td><td>C. Spiniello\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/OSIRIS\u00a0</td><td>T. Treu\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN004\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN004\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>. OSIRIS is the OH-Suppressing Infra-Red Imaging Spectrograph (Larkin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). Details of the LRIS observations for B1608+656 are in Suyu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib157\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib157\" data-open=\"bib157\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), for RXJ1131\u22121231 are in Suyu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib160\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib160\" data-open=\"bib160\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), and for HE\u00a00435\u22121223 are in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib187\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib187\" data-open=\"bib187\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper IV</a>; other observations are in forthcoming publications. Only one-sixth of the HE\u00a01104\u22121805 observations with X-shooter (Vernet et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib176\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib176\" data-open=\"bib176\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) were obtained, which were insufficient for measuring the lens velocity dispersion. The observations with OSIRIS are pending.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/74112321\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=74112322 id=\"74112322\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 COSMOGRAPHY AND ASTROPHYSICS WITH HE\u00a00435\u22121223: KEY COMPONENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We summarize the key ingredients and analysis of HE\u00a00435\u22121223 that are described in upcoming publications of the H0LiCOW project (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib144\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib144\" data-open=\"bib144\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Papers II</a>\u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">V</a>). The titles of the papers begin with \u2018H0LiCOW\u2019, followed by the specific titles written below.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">II. Spectroscopic survey and galaxy-group identification of the strong gravitational lens systems HE\u00a00435\u22121223 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib144\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib144\" data-open=\"bib144\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper II</a>). From our spectroscopic campaign of the lens environment, we present the measured spectroscopic redshifts, focusing in particular on the massive and nearby objects to the strong-lens system that are necessary ingredients for lens mass modelling and distance measurement. By combining with the spectroscopic catalogue of independent efforts (Momcheva et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib98\" data-open=\"bib98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), we identify potential galaxy groups towards HE\u00a00435\u22121223 in order to control the systematic effect due to the galaxies along the line of sight. We use the flexion shift<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn7\" data-open=\"fn7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>7</sup></a> introduced by McCully et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) to determine which mass structures (galaxies/groups) need to be incorporated explicitly in the lens mass model and which could be well approximated by an external shear/convergence field. The flexion-shift analysis presented in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib144\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib144\" data-open=\"bib144\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper II</a> shows that the most significant line-of-sight perturber is the galaxy G1 that is closest to the lens system, which justifies our inclusion of this particular galaxy in all of our strong-lensing models in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib187\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib187\" data-open=\"bib187\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper IV</a>. Furthermore, the next four nearest perturbers from the lens system may also produce higher order perturbations on the lens potential, and we account for the effects of these four additional galaxies in one of our systematic tests in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib187\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib187\" data-open=\"bib187\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper IV</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">III. Quantifying the effect of mass along the line of sight to the gravitational lens HE\u00a00435\u22121223 through weighted galaxy counts (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib134\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib134\" data-open=\"bib134\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper III</a>). Using the wide-field photometry and spectroscopy in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.3</a>, we compute photometric redshifts and stellar masses for objects in the field up to 120 arcsec from the strong lens, and with <em>i</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a024\u00a0mag. We thoroughly test the weighted galaxy number counts technique of Greene et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), and apply it to HE\u00a00435\u22121223 with the CFHTLenS survey (Heymans et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) as the control field. By comparing the weighted counts to simulated lines of sight that are ray traced through numerical simulations (Hilbert et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>), we infer the distribution for the external convergence \u03ba<sub>ext</sub> that excludes the strong-lens redshift plane.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">IV. Lens mass model of HE\u00a00435\u22121223 and blind measurement of its time-delay distance for cosmology (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib187\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib187\" data-open=\"bib187\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper IV</a>). Using the time delays from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper V</a> and our <em>HST</em>/WFC3-IR imaging (<em>F</em>160<em>W</em>) and archival <em>HST</em>/ACS observations (<em>F</em>555<em>W</em> and <em>F</em>814<em>W</em>), we model the lens mass distribution including explicitly the nearest, in projection from HE\u00a00435\u22121223, one (G1) or five (G1 plus the next four nearest/brightest) perturbers, with spectroscopic redshifts from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib144\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib144\" data-open=\"bib144\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper II</a>. We then incorporate the velocity dispersion of the lens galaxy, and the external convergence distribution from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib134\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib134\" data-open=\"bib134\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper III</a> to infer an effective time-delay distance, which is blinded during the analysis stage. We unblind only after the completion of the analysis, and publish these results without modifications.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">V. New COSMOGRAIL time delays of HE\u00a00435\u22121223: <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> to 3.8\u00a0per\u00a0cent from strong lensing in flat-\u039bCDM (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper V</a>). We present the 13-yr monitoring of HE\u00a00435\u22121223 and measure the time delays between the image pairs. Using the resulting effective time-delay distance of HE\u00a00435\u22121223 from the blind analysis in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib187\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib187\" data-open=\"bib187\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper IV</a>, we create a Time Delay Strong Lensing (TDSL) probe with HE\u00a00435\u22121223, RXJ1131\u22121231 and B1608+656 (we note that the analysis of RXJ1131\u22121231 was also blinded in Suyu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib160\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib160\" data-open=\"bib160\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), whereas the analysis of B1608+656 was not as it was the first lens to be analysed using our modelling techniques). We infer cosmological constraints from TDSL alone, and combine it with other cosmological probes to constrain various cosmological models.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition to the above, there are more forthcoming publications. The study of the AGN host galaxy properties based on simulations are described in H0LiCOW Paper VI (Ding et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). The newly developed multilens plane modelling, based on the multilens plane equations (Schneider et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib138\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib138\" data-open=\"bib138\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1992</a>; Blandford &amp; Kochanek\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>), and PSF reconstruction will be detailed by Suyu et\u00a0al. (in preparation). The weak-lensing analysis of the field of HE\u00a00435\u22121223 will be presented by Tihhonova et\u00a0al. (in preparation). Following these publications, there will be the next studies and analysis of the remaining sample (WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a01104\u22121805).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=74112329 id=\"74112329\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>6 H0LICOW COSMOGRAPHIC FORECAST</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We make predictions of the cosmographic constraints based on our sample of H0LiCOW lenses. We use the time-delay distance measurements for B1608+656 (equation 35 of Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib157\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib157\" data-open=\"bib157\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), RXJ1131\u22121231 (equation 5 of Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib161\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib161\" data-open=\"bib161\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) and HE\u00a00435\u22121223 (equation 17 of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib187\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib187\" data-open=\"bib187\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper IV</a>). For the forecasted time-delay distance measurements of the other two lenses, we adopt an uncertainty with contributions from the time delays, mass modelling and external convergence added in quadrature. Specifically, we estimate time-delay uncertainties of 4\u2009per\u2009cent and 2\u2009per\u2009cent, modelling uncertainties of 4\u2009per\u2009cent and 8\u2009per\u2009cent, external convergence uncertainties of 4\u2009per\u2009cent and 4\u2009per\u2009cent, yielding a total uncertainty of 7\u2009per\u2009cent and 9\u2009per\u2009cent for WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a01104\u22121805, respectively. Furthermore, we assume that the angular diameter distance to each lens can be measured with an uncertainty of 15\u2009per\u2009cent using our current data sets (Jee et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). More precise measurements of <em>D</em><sub>d</sub> (\u223c5\u201310\u2009per\u2009cent uncertainty) would require additional kinematic data of the lens galaxy beyond what we currently have, particularly spatially resolved kinematics maps. For the forecasted <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> and <em>D</em><sub>d</sub> constraints, we adopt a fiducial cosmological model with <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = 72\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u2212 1</sup>, \u03a9<sub>m</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01\u00a0\u2212\u00a0\u03a9<sub>DE</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.32, and <em>w</em>\u00a0=\u00a0\u22121 to predict the distances with their estimated uncertainties mentioned above, although we note that this assumption affects little the fractional uncertainty, which is nearly scale-free.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We show in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, the cosmographic constraints of our sample of lenses with uniform priors on the cosmological parameters (left-column panels), in combination with <em>WMAP</em> 9-yr results (Hinshaw et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>, middle-left-column panels), and in combination with <em>Planck</em> 2015 results (Planck Collaboration XIII\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib120\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib120\" data-open=\"bib120\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>, middle-right-column panels)<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn8\" data-open=\"fn8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>8</sup></a> for three different background cosmologies: (1) open \u039bCDM with variable spatial curvature \u03a9<sub>k</sub> (top row), (2) spatially flat <em>w</em>CDM with <em>w</em> as the time-independent dark energy equation of state (middle row) and (3) flat \u039bCDM with varying effective number of relativistic species <em>N</em><sub>eff</sub> (bottom row). In the right-column panels, we show the one-dimensional marginalized constraints of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> of our sample of lenses alone or in combination with the CMB data sets (i.e. marginalized <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> distributions of the panels to the left), as indicated in the legend. We list in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> the prior ranges for the uniform background cosmologies. The <em>WMAP</em> 9-yr and <em>Planck</em> chains have a prior with <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> &lt; 100\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u2212 1</sup> imposed. The cosmographic constraints of our lenses shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> (from the forecasted measurements of <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> and <em>D</em><sub>d</sub>) mostly stem from the <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> measurements as a results of the substantially smaller uncertainties of <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> than that of <em>D</em><sub>d</sub>. In fact, the cosmographic constraints from <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> alone would increase the <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> 1\u03c3 uncertainties shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> by at most 0.8\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u2212 1</sup> (depending on the background cosmology). The additional cosmographic information from <em>D</em><sub>d</sub> would become more significant when the <em>D</em><sub>d</sub> uncertainties are reduced to \u223c5\u201310\u2009per\u2009cent (Jee et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"74112332\" scrollto-destination=\"74112332\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/468/3/10.1093_mnras_stx483/1/m_stx483fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466631&amp;Signature=l2IX7FIAJm9-ZiNbHleqHUhokOpMsOgLRlKi21c66YpF7dA~wesxLjInfqfOcbffkj8ZgoNeOrP0tNjxzqCGBWzYx358s5JBtNzPNLK9ZkaTqyGsuPYTGWhkjp0dbx3OGMwaUROcSPpTz~aRzQZAh2XS5KTK7m4Wl2nE0k~nIuLscDMfBq7jNLEESXIJuUK4In2VzGsD4yBDXAionpMrC1gCIOAhy8OQeE2PSemO3Oej9W40UsTNMDdxVE9WQonU43~Rau1S8ilBlXWmpJUchLTAsZTze5TOdqlslrduTVPN26IHilIr46ckXO0uaSnu1nKo-0rBK-Z-Y0jSwfIvsA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Forecasted cosmographic constraints from the H0LiCOW lens sample through measurements of D\u0394t and Dd. Columns from left to right are, respectively, the constraints from the H0LiCOW lenses alone (with uniform prior on cosmological parameters), lenses in combination with WMAP 9-yr results, lenses in combination with Planck 2015 results, and marginalized constraints on H0 from the previous three columns. The H0LiCOW lenses primarily constrain H0, which in turn break CMB parameter degeneracies to elucidate the spatial curvature of universe (\u03a9k, top row), dark energy equation of state (w, middle row) and effective number of relativistic species (Neff, bottom row). H0LiCOW lenses provide an independent, complementary and competitive probe of cosmology.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx483fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/74112332/stx483fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx483fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"74112332\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/468/3/10.1093_mnras_stx483/1/stx483fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466631&Signature=xYUpz5AhLVuIgduS3uzgjGre5G-4C8rh5kefT9CM-rgIdPTK7bNXUNgdtZM3L2EYTmoQYo6PqD8oCjBaNFnM2Bo2L96DGoY31YnXSTEw3r81QmS5jdUpFw~J5z2CAkw2~SWF5RnE3lG30~LCDf9h3vVxpFWph2cklTlm5TrwUK0IluzYgMLSDMkTw5q2vrCYtL-AAxHOFg-QpbNW1xC0Wd8Kit9KW8K2VhGtO45~mnPPbroOWG42MadDb6cHR~oPliMoYvxj-gl3WN7UtCt8xABVv3~s9vgbyIRXRTurjcjk~30MMvfrdv~Qreqk95OwSpNMINWHDULRrq00KrY3NQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=74112332&ar=3055701&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx483fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Forecasted cosmographic constraints from the H0LiCOW lens sample through measurements of <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> and <em>D</em><sub>d</sub>. Columns from left to right are, respectively, the constraints from the H0LiCOW lenses alone (with uniform prior on cosmological parameters), lenses in combination with <em>WMAP</em> 9-yr results, lenses in combination with <em>Planck</em> 2015 results, and marginalized constraints on <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> from the previous three columns. The H0LiCOW lenses primarily constrain <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>, which in turn break CMB parameter degeneracies to elucidate the spatial curvature of universe (\u03a9<sub>k</sub>, top row), dark energy equation of state (<em>w</em>, middle row) and effective number of relativistic species (<em>N</em><sub>eff</sub>, bottom row). H0LiCOW lenses provide an independent, complementary and competitive probe of cosmology.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/468/3/10.1093_mnras_stx483/1/m_stx483fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466631&amp;Signature=l2IX7FIAJm9-ZiNbHleqHUhokOpMsOgLRlKi21c66YpF7dA~wesxLjInfqfOcbffkj8ZgoNeOrP0tNjxzqCGBWzYx358s5JBtNzPNLK9ZkaTqyGsuPYTGWhkjp0dbx3OGMwaUROcSPpTz~aRzQZAh2XS5KTK7m4Wl2nE0k~nIuLscDMfBq7jNLEESXIJuUK4In2VzGsD4yBDXAionpMrC1gCIOAhy8OQeE2PSemO3Oej9W40UsTNMDdxVE9WQonU43~Rau1S8ilBlXWmpJUchLTAsZTze5TOdqlslrduTVPN26IHilIr46ckXO0uaSnu1nKo-0rBK-Z-Y0jSwfIvsA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Forecasted cosmographic constraints from the H0LiCOW lens sample through measurements of D\u0394t and Dd. Columns from left to right are, respectively, the constraints from the H0LiCOW lenses alone (with uniform prior on cosmological parameters), lenses in combination with WMAP 9-yr results, lenses in combination with Planck 2015 results, and marginalized constraints on H0 from the previous three columns. The H0LiCOW lenses primarily constrain H0, which in turn break CMB parameter degeneracies to elucidate the spatial curvature of universe (\u03a9k, top row), dark energy equation of state (w, middle row) and effective number of relativistic species (Neff, bottom row). H0LiCOW lenses provide an independent, complementary and competitive probe of cosmology.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx483fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/74112332/stx483fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx483fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"74112332\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/468/3/10.1093_mnras_stx483/1/stx483fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466631&Signature=xYUpz5AhLVuIgduS3uzgjGre5G-4C8rh5kefT9CM-rgIdPTK7bNXUNgdtZM3L2EYTmoQYo6PqD8oCjBaNFnM2Bo2L96DGoY31YnXSTEw3r81QmS5jdUpFw~J5z2CAkw2~SWF5RnE3lG30~LCDf9h3vVxpFWph2cklTlm5TrwUK0IluzYgMLSDMkTw5q2vrCYtL-AAxHOFg-QpbNW1xC0Wd8Kit9KW8K2VhGtO45~mnPPbroOWG42MadDb6cHR~oPliMoYvxj-gl3WN7UtCt8xABVv3~s9vgbyIRXRTurjcjk~30MMvfrdv~Qreqk95OwSpNMINWHDULRrq00KrY3NQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=74112332&ar=3055701&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx483fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Forecasted cosmographic constraints from the H0LiCOW lens sample through measurements of <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> and <em>D</em><sub>d</sub>. Columns from left to right are, respectively, the constraints from the H0LiCOW lenses alone (with uniform prior on cosmological parameters), lenses in combination with <em>WMAP</em> 9-yr results, lenses in combination with <em>Planck</em> 2015 results, and marginalized constraints on <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> from the previous three columns. The H0LiCOW lenses primarily constrain <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>, which in turn break CMB parameter degeneracies to elucidate the spatial curvature of universe (\u03a9<sub>k</sub>, top row), dark energy equation of state (<em>w</em>, middle row) and effective number of relativistic species (<em>N</em><sub>eff</sub>, bottom row). H0LiCOW lenses provide an independent, complementary and competitive probe of cosmology.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"74112333\" scrollto-destination=\"74112333\"></a>\r\n<div href=\"/view-large/74112333\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl5\" data-id=\"tbl5\"><span class=\"label\">Table 5.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Prior for \u2018uniform\u2019 cosmological models.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Cosmology<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Prior ranges<span aria-hidden=\"true\"
