1</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u03a9<sub>m</sub> \u2208 [0, 0.5]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub> \u2208 [0.5, 1]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u03a9<sub>k</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01\u00a0\u2212\u00a0\u03a9<sub>m</sub>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0\u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Flat <em>w</em>CDM\u00a0</td><td><em>H</em><sub>0</sub> \u2208 [0, 120]\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u03a9<sub>m</sub> \u2208 [0, 1]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u03a9<sub>DE</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01\u00a0\u2212\u00a0\u03a9<sub>m</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td><em>w</em> \u2208 [\u22122.5, 0]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Flat <em>N</em><sub>eff</sub>\u039bCDM\u00a0</td><td><em>H</em><sub>0</sub> \u2208 [0, 120]\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u03a9<sub>m</sub> \u2208 [0, 1]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01\u00a0\u2212\u00a0\u03a9<sub>m</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td><em>N</em><sub>eff</sub> \u2208 [0, 10]\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Cosmology<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Prior ranges<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Open \u039bCDM\u00a0</td><td><em>H</em><sub>0</sub> \u2208 [0, 120]\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u03a9<sub>m</sub> \u2208 [0, 0.5]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub> \u2208 [0.5, 1]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u03a9<sub>k</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01\u00a0\u2212\u00a0\u03a9<sub>m</sub>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0\u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Flat <em>w</em>CDM\u00a0</td><td><em>H</em><sub>0</sub> \u2208 [0, 120]\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u03a9<sub>m</sub> \u2208 [0, 1]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u03a9<sub>DE</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01\u00a0\u2212\u00a0\u03a9<sub>m</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td><em>w</em> \u2208 [\u22122.5, 0]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Flat <em>N</em><sub>eff</sub>\u039bCDM\u00a0</td><td><em>H</em><sub>0</sub> \u2208 [0, 120]\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u03a9<sub>m</sub> \u2208 [0, 1]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01\u00a0\u2212\u00a0\u03a9<sub>m</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td><em>N</em><sub>eff</sub> \u2208 [0, 10]\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/74112333\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">As seen in the left column, the time-delay lenses primarily constrain <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>, and depend weakly (if at all) on other parameters. None the less, the time-delay distances <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> and the lenses\u2019 angular diameter distances <em>D</em><sub>d</sub> provide some information on <em>w</em>, as the constraint contours are tilted rather than being vertical. With more lenses or smaller uncertainties on <em>D</em><sub>d</sub> measurements, the constraints on cosmology become more prominent (Jee et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). However, the H0LiCOW lenses provide strong cosmographic constraints when combined with the CMB measurements since they help to break parameter degeneracies in the CMB. Thus, we should be able to place substantially better constraints on, for example, the spatial curvature, <em>w</em> and <em>N</em><sub>eff</sub> (middle two columns), compared to constraints from CMB alone. In particular, we expect better than 3.5\u00a0per\u00a0cent precision on <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> for the two cosmologies with <em>w</em>\u00a0=\u00a0\u22121 (open \u039bCDM and flat <em>N</em><sub>eff</sub>\u039bCDM)<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn9\" data-open=\"fn9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>9</sup></a>; when <em>w</em> is allowed to vary, this constraint weakens to \u223c11\u2009per\u2009cent without CMB priors and \u223c5\u2009per\u2009cent with CMB priors in the <em>w</em>CDM cosmology, as visible in the rightmost panel in the middle row. By combining our five H0LiCOW lenses with <em>Planck</em>, we expect to achieve the following precisions: \u03a9<sub>k</sub> to 0.004 in open \u039bCDM, <em>w</em> to 0.14 in flat wCDM, and <em>N</em><sub>eff</sub> to 0.2 in flat <em>N</em><sub>eff</sub>\u039bCDM (all 1\u03c3 uncertainties). These precisions are a factor of \u223c15, \u223c2, and \u223c1.5, respectively, tighter than <em>Planck</em> on its own. Our H0LiCOW sample provides not only an independent check of systematics, but also a great complement to other cosmological probes for pinning down cosmological parameters.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=74112335 id=\"74112335\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7>7 SUMMARY AND OUTLOOK</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We present the H0LiCOW program that aims to measure <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> to &lt;3.5\u2009per\u2009cent in precision and accuracy (in most background cosmological models) with a sample of five time-delay lenses, completely independent of the cosmic distance ladder and other direct measurements of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>. Our cosmographic information comes from measuring the distances to the lens systems, specifically <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> and <em>D</em><sub>d</sub>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To achieve our goal, we have obtained almost all the key ingredients for our lens sample<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn10\" data-open=\"fn10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>10</sup></a>: (1) the time delays from the COSMOGRAIL and Very Large Array monitoring, (2) high-resolution <em>HST</em> imaging for modelling the lens mass distributions, (3) wide-field imaging and spectroscopy to quantify the effects of the lens environment, and (4) lens velocity dispersion measurements to augment our lensing mass models. Our new <em>HST</em> observations reveal Einstein rings in the lens systems that allow us to perform precision lens mass modelling.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The results of our recent blind analysis of HE\u00a00435\u22121223 will appear in the companion H0LiCOW publications. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib144\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib144\" data-open=\"bib144\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper II</a> (Sluse et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib144\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib144\" data-open=\"bib144\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) presents the spectroscopic campaign on the HE\u00a00435\u22121223 field and identifies galaxy groups in the light cone containing the lens. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib134\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib134\" data-open=\"bib134\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper III</a> (Rusu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib134\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib134\" data-open=\"bib134\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) combines the spectroscopy, the wide-field imaging data, and the Millennium Simulation to derive the external convergence of the line-of-sight mass distributions. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib187\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib187\" data-open=\"bib187\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper IV</a> (Wong et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib187\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib187\" data-open=\"bib187\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) models the lens mass distribution using the <em>HST</em> data, the time delays and the lens velocity dispersion to infer the time-delay distance, that is blinded throughout the analysis. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper V</a> (Bonvin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) presents the COSMOGRAIL monitoring of HE\u00a00435\u22121223 and investigates the cosmological implications based on the three lenses (B1608+656, RXJ1131\u22121231and HE\u00a00435\u22121223) that we have so far analysed.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">With our sample of five lenses, we expect to measure <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> to &lt;3.5\u2009per\u2009cent in precision and accuracy for the non-flat \u039bCDM cosmology or flat <em>N</em><sub>eff</sub>\u039bCDM cosmology, with <em>w</em>\u00a0=\u00a0\u22121. When <em>w</em> is allowed to vary, the constraint on <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> degrades to \u223c11\u2009per\u2009cent with time-delay data only, and to \u223c5\u2009per\u2009cent when augmented with CMB data. Our independent strong-lensing distances significantly improve cosmological constraints from the <em>Planck</em> data: the precisions on \u03a9<sub>k</sub>, <em>w</em>, and <em>N</em><sub>eff</sub> improve by a factor of \u223c15, \u223c2, and 1.5, respectively, when we combine our lenses with <em>Planck</em>. Time-delay lenses are therefore highly complementary to other cosmological probes.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our data set provides an excellent opportunity to study, in addition to cosmography, galaxy formation, and evolution. For example, we can study the distribution of dark matter in the lens galaxies by combining lensing and kinematics data, and also infer the stellar mass of the lens galaxies (e.g. Treu &amp; Koopmans\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib167\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib167\" data-open=\"bib167\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Barnab\u00e8 et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib147\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib147\" data-open=\"bib147\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib148\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib148\" data-open=\"bib148\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib159\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib159\" data-open=\"bib159\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012b</a>). By separately determining the stellar mass based on either (1) stellar population synthesis using multiband photometry (e.g. Auger et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Treu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib170\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib170\" data-open=\"bib170\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Oguri, Rusu &amp; Falco\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib111\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib111\" data-open=\"bib111\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), or (2) identification/characterization of spectral features (e.g. van Dokkum &amp; Conroy\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib173\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib173\" data-open=\"bib173\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Conroy &amp; van Dokkum\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Spiniello et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib150\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib150\" data-open=\"bib150\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib151\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib151\" data-open=\"bib151\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib152\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib152\" data-open=\"bib152\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Barnab\u00e8 et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), and comparing this stellar mass to that obtained from lensing and dynamics, we can study properties of the stellar population and infer the stellar IMF slope (e.g. Grillo et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Auger et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Treu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib170\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib170\" data-open=\"bib170\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Spiniello et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib149\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib149\" data-open=\"bib149\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib152\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib152\" data-open=\"bib152\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Barnab\u00e8 et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). There are about a dozen early-type lens galaxies that have been studied in detail for constraining the stellar IMF slope individually (e.g. Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib147\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib147\" data-open=\"bib147\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Barnab\u00e8 et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Spiniello et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib152\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib152\" data-open=\"bib152\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Newman et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib107\" data-open=\"bib107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), and these galaxies are all at redshifts below 0.35. Four of our H0LiCOW lens galaxies are at redshifts between 0.45 and 0.73, which would allow us to explore the stellar IMF with comparable precisions per lens galaxy as previous studies, but at substantially higher redshifts. Given the current tension in the IMF measurement between nearby (<em>z</em><sub>d</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.06) lens galaxies and <em>z</em><sub>d</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.2\u20130.3 lens galaxies (e.g. Smith &amp; Lucey\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib146\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib146\" data-open=\"bib146\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Newman et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib107\" data-open=\"bib107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), our H0LiCOW lenses would help assess whether the tensions are just limited to those particular objects or if they reflect a more general problem in our understanding of stellar populations. In addition, our lenses are natural telescopes that magnify the background sources, allowing us to study the host galaxies of the AGNs in detail and probe the origin of the co-evolution between supermassive black holes and their host galaxies (Peng et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib115\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib115\" data-open=\"bib115\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Rusu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib133\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib133\" data-open=\"bib133\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Ding et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our H0LiCOW program aims to establish gravitational lens time delays as an independent and competitive probe of cosmology, and paves the way for determining <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> to 1\u00a0per\u00a0cent in the future. Given the hundreds, if not thousands, of time-delay lens systems that are expected to be discovered in ongoing and future surveys such as the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (e.g. Oguri et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib110\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib110\" data-open=\"bib110\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Inada et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; More et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib99\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib99\" data-open=\"bib99\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016a</a>), the Dark Energy Survey (e.g. Agnello et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), the Hyper Suprime-Cam Survey (e.g. Chan et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), the Kilo-Degree Survey (e.g. Napolitano et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib106\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib106\" data-open=\"bib106\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), Euclid and the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (Oguri &amp; Marshall\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib109\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib109\" data-open=\"bib109\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), and continuous advances in high-resolution imaging and spectroscopy in the current and next generation of telescopes for observational follow-up (Linder\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Meng et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib95\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib95\" data-open=\"bib95\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), the H0LiCOW program will provide the basis for extracting cosmological information from the wealth of strong-lensing data sets. In particular, we expect the combination of facilities at different wavelengths such as the <em>HST</em> in the optical/near-IR, <em>James Webb Space Telescope</em> in the IR, large and extremely large telescopes with adaptive optics, the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array in the submillimetre waveband, and the Square Kilometer Array in the radio, will be of great synergistic value for studying these fruitful lenses.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=74112342 id=\"74112342\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" >Acknowledgments</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We thank M. Barnab\u00e8, J. Chan, Y. Hezaveh, E. Komatsu, E. Linder, J. McKean, D. Paraficz, P. Schneider and S. The Collaborating Institutions are Argonne National Laboratory, the University of California at Santa Cruz, the University of Cambridge, Centro de Investigaciones En\u00e9rgeticas, Medioambientales y Tecnol\u00f3gicas-Madrid, the University of Chicago, University College London, the DES-Brazil Consortium, the University of Edinburgh, the Eidgen\u00f6ssische Technische Hochschule (ETH) Z\u00fcrich, Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, the Institut de Ci\u00e8ncies de l'Espai (IEEC/CSIC), the Institut de F\u00edsica d'Altes Energies, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, the Ludwig-Maximilians Universit\u00e4t M\u00fcnchen and the associated Excellence Cluster Universe, the University of Michigan, the National Optical Astronomy Observatory, the University of Nottingham, the Ohio State University, the University of Pennsylvania, the University of Portsmouth, SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory, Stanford University, the University of Sussex and Texas A&amp;M University.</p><div content-id=\"fn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" class=\"end-note-link\">1</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">In terms of its impact on <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub>.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn2\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn2\" class=\"end-note-link\">2</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">The source redshift of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.654 is based on the narrow emission lines, which is considered more accurate than the H\u00a0\u03b1 and Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> lines (Hewett &amp; Wild\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) that yield <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.657 (Sluse et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib142\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib142\" data-open=\"bib142\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>). We note that a 0.003 change in <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> corresponds to a &lt;0.4\u2009per\u2009cent change in <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> for RXJ1131\u22121231, and even less change in <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> for the other higher redshift lens systems.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn3\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn3\" class=\"end-note-link\">3</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Based on Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> emission line, which results in a slightly higher redshift value than the previous measurement of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.689 (Wisotzki et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib186\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib186\" data-open=\"bib186\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>) from C <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> line that is known to be prone to systematic blueshifts in many quasars.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn4\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn4\" class=\"end-note-link\">4</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">For HE\u00a00435\u22121223, one long exposure was lost due to a satellite passing over the target. For one of the parallelogram dither pattern for WFI2033\u22124723, we use an exposure sequence of short\u2013long (rather than short\u2013long\u2013long) at each dither position to optimize target exposure time given overhead associated with observations.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn5\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn5\" class=\"end-note-link\">5</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><span class=\"small-caps\">DrizzlePac</span> is a product of the Space Telescope Science Institute, which is operated by AURA for NASA.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn6\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn6\" class=\"end-note-link\">6</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">A lens modelling software package developed by A. Halkola and S. H. Suyu (Suyu &amp; Halkola <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib155\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib155\" data-open=\"bib155\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib159\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib159\" data-open=\"bib159\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012b</a>).</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn7\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn7\" class=\"end-note-link\">7</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">The flexion shift corresponds to the shift in the image positions due to the flexion (third-order derivatives of the lens potential) of a line-of-sight perturber. McCully et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) find through their study of simulated lens fields that perturbers with flexion shifts larger than \u223c10<sup>\u22124</sup> arcsec should be incorporated explicitly in the multiplane lens mass model. The threshold of \u223c10<sup>\u22124</sup> arcsec is conservative and is based on tests that only used image positions as constraints. It may be that using the spatially extended images for modelling would push that threshold even lower.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn8\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn8\" class=\"end-note-link\">8</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">We use the <em>Planck</em> chains designated by \u2018plikHM_TT_lowTEB\u2019 that uses the baseline high-L <em>Planck</em> power spectra and low-L temperature and LFI polarization.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn9\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn9\" class=\"end-note-link\">9</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Relative to <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = 72\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u2212 1</sup>.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn10\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn10\" class=\"end-note-link\">10</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">With spectroscopic observations of HE\u00a01104\u22121805 pending for lens velocity dispersion measurement.</p></div></span></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=74112355 id=\"74112355\" class=\"backreferences-title\" >REFERENCES</h2>\r\n<div class=\"ref-list\"><div content-id=\"bib1\" data-legacy-id=\"bib1\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a widget-SingleSection widget-instance-OUP_ViewLarge\">\n        <div content-id=\"tbl4\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl4\" data-id=\"tbl4\"><span class=\"label\">Table 4.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Spectroscopy of foreground lens as part of the H0LiCOW program.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Lens<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Facility/instrument<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Proposal PI<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>B1608+656\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/LRIS\u00a0</td><td>C. D. Fassnacht\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>RXJ1131\u22121231\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/LRIS\u00a0</td><td>C. D. Fassnacht\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/OSIRIS\u00a0</td><td>T. Treu\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HE\u00a00435\u22121223\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/LRIS\u00a0</td><td>C. D. Fassnacht\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/OSIRIS\u00a0</td><td>T. Treu\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WFI2033\u22124723\u00a0</td><td>VLT/MUSE\u00a0</td><td>D. Sluse\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HE\u00a01104\u22121805\u00a0</td><td>VLT/X-shooter\u00a0</td><td>C. Spiniello\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/OSIRIS\u00a0</td><td>T. Treu\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Lens<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Facility/instrument<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Proposal PI<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>B1608+656\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/LRIS\u00a0</td><td>C. D. Fassnacht\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>RXJ1131\u22121231\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/LRIS\u00a0</td><td>C. D. Fassnacht\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/OSIRIS\u00a0</td><td>T. Treu\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HE\u00a00435\u22121223\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/LRIS\u00a0</td><td>C. D. Fassnacht\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/OSIRIS\u00a0</td><td>T. Treu\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WFI2033\u22124723\u00a0</td><td>VLT/MUSE\u00a0</td><td>D. Sluse\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HE\u00a01104\u22121805\u00a0</td><td>VLT/X-shooter\u00a0</td><td>C. Spiniello\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/OSIRIS\u00a0</td><td>T. Treu\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN004\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN004\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>. OSIRIS is the OH-Suppressing Infra-Red Imaging Spectrograph (Larkin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span>2006). Details of the LRIS observations for B1608+656 are in Suyu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib157\"></span>2010), for RXJ1131\u22121231 are in Suyu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib160\"></span>2013), and for HE\u00a00435\u22121223 are in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib187\"></span>H0LiCOW Paper IV; other observations are in forthcoming publications. Only one-sixth of the HE\u00a01104\u22121805 observations with X-shooter (Vernet et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib176\"></span>2011) were obtained, which were insufficient for measuring the lens velocity dispersion. The observations with OSIRIS are pending.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/[XSLTSectionID][QueryString]\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl4\" data-id=\"tbl4\"><span class=\"label\">Table 4.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Spectroscopy of foreground lens as part of the H0LiCOW program.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Lens<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Facility/instrument<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Proposal PI<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>B1608+656\u00a0</td><td>W. Treu\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN004\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN004\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>. OSIRIS is the OH-Suppressing Infra-Red Imaging Spectrograph (Larkin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span>2006). Details of the LRIS observations for B1608+656 are in Suyu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib157\"></span>2010), for RXJ1131\u22121231 are in Suyu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib160\"></span>2013), and for HE\u00a00435\u22121223 are in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib187\"></span>H0LiCOW Paper IV; other observations are in forthcoming publications. class=\"widget-items\">\r\n                <h1 class=\"wi-article-title article-title-main\">\r\n                    H0LiCOW \u2013 I. <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> Lenses in COSMOGRAIL's Wellspring: program overview\r\n<i class='icon-availability_free' title='Free' ></i>                </h1>\r\n                <div class=\"wi-authors\">\r\n                    <div class=\"al-authors-list\">\r\n                            <div class=\"meta-authors--limited\">\r\n                                    <span class=\"al-author-name js-flyout-wrap\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                                        <a class=\"linked-name\" href=\"javascript:;\">S. H.        <div class=\"wi-date\">27 February 2017</div>\r\n                </div>\r\n        </div>\r\n</div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<script>\r\n    $(document).ready(function () {\r\n        $('.article-top-widget').on('click', '.ati-toggle-trigger', function () {\r\n            $(this).find('.icon-general-add, .icon-minus').toggleClass('icon-minus icon-general-add');\r\n            $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \n    </div>\n    <div     </a>\r\n                            </li>\r\n                        <li class=\"toolbar-item item-with-dropdown item-views\">\r\n                            <a class=\"at-views-dropdown class=\"toolbar-label\">\r\n                                    <div class=\"toolbar-text\">Views</div>\r\n                                    <i class=\"icon-general-arrow-filled-down arrow-icon\"></i>\r\n                                </div>\r\n                            </a>\r\n                            <ul id=\"ViewsDrop\" class=\"f-dropdown\" data-dropdown-content aria-label=\"submenu\">\r\n                                <div class=\"arrow-up\"></div>\r\n                                <li class=\"article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"article-content\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Article contents</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                                <li class=\"at-figures-tables article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"figures-tables\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Figures &amp; tables</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                                <li class=\"article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"video\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Video</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                                <li class=\"article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"audio\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Audio</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                                <li class=\"article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"supplementary-data\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Supplementary Data</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                            </ul>\r\n                        </li>\r\n                        <li class=\"toolbar-item\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ToolboxGetCitation widget-instance-OUP_Get_Citation\">\n        <a href=\"#\" class=\"js-cite-button\" data-reveal-id=\"getCitation\" data-reveal><i class=\"icon-read-more\"></i><span>Cite</span></a>\r\n\r\n<div id=\"getCitation\" class=\"reveal-modal\" data-reveal>\r\n    <h3 class=\"modal-title\">Cite</h3>\r\n        <div class=\"oxford-citation-text\">\r\n            <p>S. H. Suyu, V. Bonvin, F. Courbin, C. D. Fassnacht, C. E. Rusu, D. Sluse, T. Treu, K. C. Wong, M. W. Auger, X. Ding, S. Hilbert, P. J. Marshall, N. Rumbaugh, A. Sonnenfeld, M. Tewes, O. Tihhonova, A. Agnello, R. D. Blandford, G. C.-F. Chen, T. Collett, L. V. E. Koopmans, K. Liao, G. Meylan, C. Spiniello,  H0LiCOW \u2013 I. <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> Lenses in COSMOGRAIL's Wellspring: program overview, <em>Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</em>, Volume 468, Issue 3, July 2017, Pages 2590\u20132604, <a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/stx483\">https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/stx483</a></p>\r\n        </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"citation-download-wrap\">\r\n        <form widget-instance-OUP_Get_Permissions\">\n            <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n        <a href=\"https://s100.copyright.com/AppDispatchServlet?publisherName=OUP&amp;publication=1365-2966&amp;title=H0LiCOW%20%E2%80%93%20I.%20%26lt%3Bem%26gt%3BH%26lt%3B%2Fem%26gt%3B%26lt%3Bsub%26gt%3B0%26lt%3B%2Fsub%26gt%3B%20Lenses%20in%20COSMOGRAIL%26apos%3Bs%20Wellspring%3A%20program%20overview&amp;publicationDate=2017-02-27&amp;volumeNum=468&amp;issueNum=3&amp;author=Suyu%2C%20S.%20H.%3B%20Bonvin%2C%20V.&amp;startPage=2590&amp;endPage=2604&amp;contentId=10.1093%2Fmnras%2Fstx483&amp;oa=&amp;copyright=Oxford%20University%20Press&amp;orderBeanReset=True\" class=\"dropdown-signin-form\">\r\n                        <div class=\"spinner\"></div>\r\n                    </li>\r\n                </ul>\r\n            </li>\r\n                <li class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                        <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-institution dummy-link\">\r\n                            Eccles Health Sci       <nav class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close js_close-navsearch\">Close</a>\r\n                    <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                        <div id=\"MicrositeSearch\" class=\"microsite-search\">\r\n                            <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter\" id=\"navbar-search-filter\">\r\n                                                                    <optgroup label=\"Search within this journal\">\r\n label=\"Search beyond this journal\">\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Parent\" >All  RAS Journals</option>\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Journals\" >All  Journals</option>\r\n                                    </optgroup>\r\n                            </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input microsite-search-term\" type=\"text\" maxlength=\"255\" id=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" title=\"search input\">\r\n\r\n                            <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MicrositeSearchIcon\" class=\"microsite-search-icon navbar-search-submit icon-menu_search\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search</span></a>\r\n\r\n                        </div>\r\n                    </div>                <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=74112271 id=\"74112271\" class=\"abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Strong gravitational lens systems with time delays between the multiple images allow measurements of time-delay distances, which are primarily sensitive to the Hubble constant that is key to probing dark energy, neutrino physics and the spatial curvature of the Universe, as well as discovering new physics. We present H0LiCOW (<em>H</em><sub>0</sub> Lenses in COSMOGRAIL's Wellspring), a program that aims to measure <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> with &lt;3.5\u2009per\u2009cent uncertainty from five lens systems (B1608+656, RXJ1131\u22121231, HE\u00a00435\u22121223, WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a01104\u22121805). We have been acquiring (1) time delays through COSMOGRAIL and Very Large Array monitoring, (2) high-resolution <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> imaging for the lens mass modelling, (3) wide-field imaging and spectroscopy to characterize the lens environment and (4) moderate-resolution spectroscopy to obtain the stellar velocity dispersion of the lenses for mass modelling. In cosmological models with one-parameter extension to flat \u039b cold dark matter, we expect to measure <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> to &lt;3.5\u2009per\u2009cent in most models, spatial curvature \u03a9<sub>k</sub> to 0.004, <em>w</em> to 0.14 and the effective number of neutrino species to 0.2 (1\u03c3 uncertainties) when combined with current cosmic microwave background (CMB) experiments. These are, respectively, a factor of \u223c15, \u223c2 and \u223c1.5 tighter than CMB alone. Our data set will further enable us to study the stellar initial mass function of the lens galaxies, and the co-evolution of supermassive black holes and their host galaxies. This program will provide a foundation for extracting cosmological distances from the hundreds of time-delay lenses that are expected to be discovered in current and future surveys.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;quasars: individual: B1608+656, RXJ1131\u22121231, HE\u00a00435\u22121223, WFI2033\u22124723, HE\u00a01104\u22121805&quot;\">quasars: individual: B1608+656, RXJ1131\u22121231, HE\u00a00435\u22121223, WFI2033\u22124723, HE\u00a01104\u22121805</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: structure&quot;\">galaxies: structure</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;cosmological parameters&quot;\">cosmological parameters</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;distance scale&quot;\">distance scale</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=74112273 id=\"74112273\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In the past decade, the so-called flat \u039b cold dark matter (\u039bCDM) cosmological model consisting of dark energy (with density characterized by a cosmological constant \u039b) and CDM in a spatially flat Universe has emerged as the standard cosmological model. This simple model has provided excellent fit to various cosmological observations including the temperature anisotropies in the cosmic microwave background (CMB) and galaxy density correlations in baryon acoustic oscillations (BAO). Recent CMB experiments, particularly the <em>Wilkinson Microwave Anisotropy Probe</em> (<em>WMAP</em>; Komatsu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib84\" data-open=\"bib84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Hinshaw et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) and the <em>Planck</em> satellite (Planck Collaboration XVI\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib119\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib119\" data-open=\"bib119\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Planck Collaboration XIII\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib120\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib120\" data-open=\"bib120\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), and BAO surveys (e.g. Anderson et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Kazin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Ross et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib131\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib131\" data-open=\"bib131\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), have yielded stringent constraints with unprecedented precision on cosmological parameters in the spatially flat \u039bCDM model.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">An interesting result from <em>Planck</em> is its predicted value of the Hubble constant (<em>H</em><sub>0</sub>), a key cosmological parameter that sets the present-day expansion rate as well as the age, size and critical density of the Universe. <em>Planck</em> does not directly measure <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>, but rather enables its indirect inference through measurements of combinations of cosmological parameters given assumptions of the background cosmological model. Intriguingly, <em>Planck</em>\u2019s value of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = 67.8 \u00b1 0.9\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u2212 1</sup> (Planck Collaboration XIII\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib120\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib120\" data-open=\"bib120\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), from <em>Planck</em> temperature data and <em>Planck</em> lensing under the flat \u039bCDM model, is lower than recent direct measurements based on the distance ladder, of 73.24 \u00b1 1.74\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u2212 1</sup> from the SH0ES program (Riess et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib128\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib128\" data-open=\"bib128\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) and of 74.3 \u00b1 2.1\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u2212 1</sup> (Freedman et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) from the Carnegie-Chicago Hubble Program (Beaton et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). On the other hand, <em>Planck</em>\u2019s <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> value is similar to the results of some of the megamaser measurements (e.g. <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = 68.9 \u00b1 7.1\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u2212 1</sup> from Reid et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib125\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib125\" data-open=\"bib125\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$H_0=73^{+26}_{-22}\\,\\rm km\\,s^{-1}\\,Mpc^{-1}$|</span> from Kuo et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib87\" data-open=\"bib87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a> and <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = 66.0 \u00b1 6.0\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u2212 1</sup> from Gao et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), although the uncertainties of these maser <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> measurements are still substantial relative to that of <em>Planck</em>. A 1\u00a0per\u00a0cent <em>direct</em> measurement of the Hubble constant is highly needed: such 1\u00a0per\u00a0cent measurements of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> would address the possible tension with the CMB value which, if significant, would point towards deviations from the standard flat \u039bCDM and new physics. In fact, when one relaxes, for example, the flatness or \u039b assumption in the CMB analysis, strong parameter degeneracies between <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> and other cosmological parameters appear, and the degenerate <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> values from the CMB become compatible with the local <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> measurements from the distance ladder (Freedman et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Planck Collaboration XIII\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib120\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib120\" data-open=\"bib120\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Riess et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib128\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib128\" data-open=\"bib128\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Thus, a 1\u00a0per\u00a0cent measurement of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> is crucial for understanding the nature of dark energy, neutrino physics, the spatial curvature of the Universe and the validity of General Relativity (e.g. Hu\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib158\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib158\" data-open=\"bib158\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012a</a>; Weinberg et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib182\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib182\" data-open=\"bib182\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). In particular, the dark energy figure of merit of any survey that does not directly measure <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> improves by \u223c40\u2009per\u2009cent if <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> is known to 1\u00a0per\u00a0cent. Furthermore, independent methods to measure <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> are necessary to overcome systematic effects, such as the known unknowns (e.g. the effects of crowding or metallicity dependence in the cosmic distance ladder) and the unknown unknowns in order to robustly verify or rule out the standard cosmological paradigm.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Strong gravitational lenses with measured time delays between the multiple images provide a competitive approach to measuring the Hubble constant, completely independent of the local distance ladder: we have demonstrated that we can constrain <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> to \u223c7\u20138\u2009per\u2009cent precision from a single time-delay lens system with ancillary data (Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib157\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib157\" data-open=\"bib157\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib161\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib161\" data-open=\"bib161\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). The time-delay method was first proposed by Refsdal (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib124\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib124\" data-open=\"bib124\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1964</a>) even before the discovery of the first strong gravitational lens system (Walsh, Carswell &amp; Weymann\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib180\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib180\" data-open=\"bib180\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1979</a>), consisting of a foreground mass distribution that is located close along the line of sight to a background source (see Treu &amp; Marshall\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib168\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib168\" data-open=\"bib168\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>, for a recent review). The light from the background source is deflected by the foreground \u2018lens\u2019 mass distribution; such light bending produces distorted and, in rare cases of \u2018strong lensing\u2019, multiple and often spectacular images of the background source (e.g. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"74112277\" scrollto-destination=\"74112277\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/468/3/10.1093_mnras_stx483/1/m_stx483fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611466631&amp;Signature=ag1Uz7eS61cDK~pm3x9pAxpymTcPDCNpkjyNUFA7iPykmQjoROvoEUXw0Jry4NMSXbKp1EF1vU~nDcvZEnkpQen8PFF8tEKdjHypcmCnsAXAV~D0ohwNlDegy0jlolzYf7DD29JhV1qRxpyOciWAkAxlRvkEiikqf~78WDA7nyTG6qzL3kb6hou0YanKa0VjGjq8JU1VRspMPh4WSoJX6FKFrpIDAPQ3iPhFTT625ISF9OQzvzFizajjihSglLsey-WZgBxqIMNRvg~39V79ni9aJkoo8Bsah4~BGI86MfLAVzp0z4pJz1Phc7UrTN5bUvL-ILSrz9-Va9K~P4u59g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"H0LiCOW lens sample, consisting of four quadruply lensed quasar systems in various configurations and one doubly lensed quasar system. The lens name is indicated above each panel. The colour images are composed using two (for B1608+656) or three (for other lenses) HST imaging bands in the optical and near-infrared. North is up and east is left.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx483fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/74112277/stx483fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx483fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"74112277\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/468/3/10.1093_mnras_stx483/1/stx483fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611466631&Signature=DIO8gvoiyTnJXo-I2LYkdeM4Py-koADOGEJVSPJVxZCwjAQ4wwIfwH-qWafAGXC2aZu50MT6V4iwky70Z4qXEjmqEMX78yC6QZbwOTi5RnVldIBU8YOlAXihtnD05GyslqMexnfJgBsjW4mcdHpRtsJfKzq5ehVM5dgHxJg0b-H-RBGw4XofYq5Bi6qaDdb8mLUbc7hBMTsYFBkytjY9NEOhTR1oNZUGemouehv4n9~iEwKmxHfztgz-kmb76vic4P~E8ltSJ1W~Yn0WGhnTblE~wpJz1uDuQTqSijYoKQpiVerEeoSSQ9~p0F11lVyi9Wh4zE2hQOS-oB6znUq~xg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=74112277&ar=3055701&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx483fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">H0LiCOW lens sample, consisting of four quadruply lensed quasar systems in various configurations and one doubly lensed quasar system. The lens name is indicated above each panel. The colour images are composed using two (for B1608+656) or three (for other lenses) <em>HST</em> imaging bands in the optical and near-infrared. North is up and east is left.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/468/3/10.1093_mnras_stx483/1/m_stx483fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611466631&amp;Signature=ag1Uz7eS61cDK~pm3x9pAxpymTcPDCNpkjyNUFA7iPykmQjoROvoEUXw0Jry4NMSXbKp1EF1vU~nDcvZEnkpQen8PFF8tEKdjHypcmCnsAXAV~D0ohwNlDegy0jlolzYf7DD29JhV1qRxpyOciWAkAxlRvkEiikqf~78WDA7nyTG6qzL3kb6hou0YanKa0VjGjq8JU1VRspMPh4WSoJX6FKFrpIDAPQ3iPhFTT625ISF9OQzvzFizajjihSglLsey-WZgBxqIMNRvg~39V79ni9aJkoo8Bsah4~BGI86MfLAVzp0z4pJz1Phc7UrTN5bUvL-ILSrz9-Va9K~P4u59g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"H0LiCOW lens sample, consisting of four quadruply lensed quasar systems in various configurations and one doubly lensed quasar system. The lens name is indicated above each panel. The colour images are composed using two (for B1608+656) or three (for other lenses) HST imaging bands in the optical and near-infrared. North is up and east is left.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx483fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/74112277/stx483fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx483fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"74112277\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/468/3/10.1093_mnras_stx483/1/stx483fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611466631&Signature=DIO8gvoiyTnJXo-I2LYkdeM4Py-koADOGEJVSPJVxZCwjAQ4wwIfwH-qWafAGXC2aZu50MT6V4iwky70Z4qXEjmqEMX78yC6QZbwOTi5RnVldIBU8YOlAXihtnD05GyslqMexnfJgBsjW4mcdHpRtsJfKzq5ehVM5dgHxJg0b-H-RBGw4XofYq5Bi6qaDdb8mLUbc7hBMTsYFBkytjY9NEOhTR1oNZUGemouehv4n9~iEwKmxHfztgz-kmb76vic4P~E8ltSJ1W~Yn0WGhnTblE~wpJz1uDuQTqSijYoKQpiVerEeoSSQ9~p0F11lVyi9Wh4zE2hQOS-oB6znUq~xg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=74112277&ar=3055701&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx483fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">H0LiCOW lens sample, consisting of four quadruply lensed quasar systems in various configurations and one doubly lensed quasar system. The lens name is indicated above each panel. The colour images are composed using two (for B1608+656) or three (for other lenses) <em>HST</em> imaging bands in the optical and near-infrared. North is up and east is left.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">When the background source is one that varies in its luminosity, such as an active galactic nucleus (AGN; e.g. Vanderriest et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib174\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib174\" data-open=\"bib174\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1989</a>; Schechter et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib135\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib135\" data-open=\"bib135\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>; Fassnacht et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Kochanek et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Courbin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) or a supernova (SN; e.g. Quimby et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib123\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib123\" data-open=\"bib123\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Kelly et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Goobar et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Grillo et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Kawamata et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; More et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib100\" data-open=\"bib100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016b</a>; Treu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib171\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib171\" data-open=\"bib171\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), the variability is manifest in each of the multiple images, but delayed in time relative to each other due to the different light paths. This time delay (\u0394<em>t</em>) thus depends on the \u2018time-delay distance\u2019 (<em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub>) and the lens mass distribution. Specifically, \u0394<em>t</em>\u00a0=\u00a0<em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub>\u0394\u03d5/<em>c</em>, where \u0394\u03d5 is the Fermat potential difference that is determined by the lens mass distribution and <em>c</em> is the speed of light. Therefore, by measuring the time delay from photometric light curves of the quasar images and modelling the lens mass distribution, one can determine the time-delay distance to the lens system and use the distance\u2013redshift relation to constrain cosmological models.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">More precisely, the time-delay distance is <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\nD_{\\Delta t}\\equiv (1+z_{\\rm d}) \\frac{D_{\\rm d}D_{\\rm s}}{D_{\\rm ds}}\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>(Refsdal\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib124\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib124\" data-open=\"bib124\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1964</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib157\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib157\" data-open=\"bib157\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), where <em>z</em><sub>d</sub> is the redshift of the foreground deflector (also referred to as the strong lens), <em>D</em><sub>d</sub> is the angular diameter distance to the deflector, <em>D</em><sub>s</sub> is the angular diameter distance to the source and <em>D</em><sub>ds</sub> is the angular diameter distance between the deflector and the source. This time-delay distance is for a single strong-lens plane, with other line-of-sight mass distributions only weakly perturbing the strong-lens system and characterized via external shear and convergence. For cases where there are massive line-of-sight mass distributions at a different redshift from the strong-lens galaxy yet close in projection to it such that these massive structures cannot be well approximated by an external shear/convergence, it is necessary to use the multiplane lensing formalism (e.g. Blandford &amp; Narayan\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1986</a>; Schneider, Ehlers &amp; Falco\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib138\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib138\" data-open=\"bib138\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1992</a>). In general, multilens plane ray tracing does not yield a single time-delay distance but rather several combinations of distances. None the less, even in some of these cases, we can derive an effective time-delay distance.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">As a result of the unique combination of these three angular diameter distances, the time-delay distance <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> is primarily sensitive to the Hubble constant, in contrast to other non-local distance probes such as SN that probe relative luminosity distances (e.g. Riess et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib127\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib127\" data-open=\"bib127\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>; Perlmutter et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib117\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib117\" data-open=\"bib117\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>; Conley et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Suzuki et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib163\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib163\" data-open=\"bib163\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Betoule et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) and BAO (e.g. Eisenstein et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; Percival et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib116\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib116\" data-open=\"bib116\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Blake et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Anderson et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) that yield absolute angular diameter distances. We note though that BAO, together with the CMB, can be used to calibrate the absolute magnitude of SN; assuming that the absolute magnitude of SN does not evolve with redshift, this combination of BAO and SN provides an \u2018inverse-distance ladder\u2019 for the Hubble constant that is insensitive to assumptions on dark energy properties and spatial curvature (e.g. Heavens, Jimenez &amp; Verde\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Aubourg et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). While BAO and the time-delay method both provide angular diameter distance measurements, the distinction is that BAO gives angular diameter distances at specific redshifts whereas the time-delay method yields time-delay distances (<em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub>) which are each a combination of three angular diameter distances. One could in fact determine the angular diameter distance to the lens <em>D</em><sub>d</sub> in addition to <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> for time-delay lenses that have stellar velocity dispersion measurements of the foreground lens galaxy (Paraficz &amp; Hjorth\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib113\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib113\" data-open=\"bib113\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Jee, Komatsu &amp; Suyu\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Without time delays, lenses with stellar velocity dispersion measurements can still offer a way to determine the cosmological matter and dark energy density parameters via a ratio of angular diameter distances (e.g. Futamase &amp; Hamana\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>; Futamase &amp; Yoshida\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>; Grillo, Lombardi &amp; Bertin\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). Recently, Jee et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) have shown that measurements of <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> and <em>D</em><sub>d</sub> from a modest sample of time-delay lenses with lens velocity dispersion measurements yield competitive constraints on cosmological models. In practice, both distances appear as intermediate quantities between the sought after cosmological parameters and the observed quantities.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to measure distances precisely and accurately from time-delay lenses, we need four key ingredients in addition to the spectroscopic redshifts of the lens and the source: (1) time delays, (2) high-resolution and high signal-to-noise ratio images of the lens systems, (3) characterization of the lens environment and (4) stellar velocity dispersion of the lens galaxy. These can be obtained via imaging and spectroscopy from <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) and ground-based observatories. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>, we detail each of these requirements.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We initiated the H0LiCOW (<em>H</em><sub>0</sub> Lenses in COSMOGRAIL's Wellspring) program with the aim of measuring the Hubble constant with better than 3.5\u2009per\u2009cent precision and accuracy (in most background cosmological models), through a sample of five time-delay lenses. We obtain the key ingredients to each of the lenses through observational follow-ups and novel analysis techniques. In particular, we have high-quality lensed quasar light curves, primarily obtained via optical monitoring by the COSMOGRAIL (COSmological MOnitoring of GRAvItational Lenses; e.g. Courbin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; Vuissoz et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib179\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib179\" data-open=\"bib179\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Courbin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Tewes et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib165\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib165\" data-open=\"bib165\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013b</a>) and Kochanek et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) teams but also via radio-wavelength monitoring (Fassnacht et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>). COSMOGRAIL has been monitoring more than 20 lensed quasars for more than a decade. The unprecedented quality of the light curves combined with new curve-shifting algorithms (Tewes, Courbin &amp; Meylan\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib164\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib164\" data-open=\"bib164\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013a</a>) lead to time delays with typically \u223c3\u00a0per\u00a0cent accuracy (Fassnacht et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Courbin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Tewes et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib165\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib165\" data-open=\"bib165\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013b</a>). In addition, we obtain <em>HST</em> imaging that reveal the \u2018Einstein ring\u2019 of the lens systems in high resolution, and develop state-of-the-art lens modelling techniques (Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib156\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib156\" data-open=\"bib156\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Suyu &amp; Halkola\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib155\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib155\" data-open=\"bib155\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib159\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib159\" data-open=\"bib159\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012b</a>) and kinematic modelling methods (Auger et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib147\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib147\" data-open=\"bib147\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) to obtain the lens mass distribution with a few percent uncertainty (e.g. Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib160\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib160\" data-open=\"bib160\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib161\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib161\" data-open=\"bib161\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). We further obtain wide-field imaging and spectroscopy to characterize the environment of the field, as well as the spectroscopy of the lens galaxy to obtain the stellar velocity dispersion. The exquisite follow-up data set that we have acquired allow us not only to constrain cosmology but also to study lens galaxy and source properties for understanding galaxy evolution, including the dark matter distribution in galaxies, the stellar initial mass function of galaxies and the co-evolution between supermassive black holes and their host galaxies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A crucial aspect of our program is the use of blind analysis (e.g. Conley et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Suzuki et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib163\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib163\" data-open=\"bib163\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib160\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib160\" data-open=\"bib160\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; von der Linden et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib177\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib177\" data-open=\"bib177\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) to test for residual systematics and avoid subconscious experimenter bias. In particular, we have developed core analysis techniques for the first lens whose dissection was not blinded (B1608+656; Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib157\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib157\" data-open=\"bib157\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>); we subsequently build upon these techniques and perform blind analysis on the other lenses in the sample. In the blind analysis, the idea is not to blind all the model parameters being inferred, but rather just the cosmological parameters that we aim to measure (as well as any derived parameters or summary statistics from which we could infer the cosmological parameters). We therefore blind the time-delay distance and all cosmological parameters in our analysis. Specifically, throughout the analysis, we only ever plot these blinded parameters offset by their posterior median value.
