We can then still use the parameter correlations and the uncertainties to cross check our analysis, since the temptation to stop investigating systematic errors when the \u2018right answer\u2019 has been obtained has been removed. Only when the collaboration deems the analysis to be final and complete do we \u2018open the box\u2019 to reveal the median values of the parameters, and then publish these results without modifications.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper (hereafter H0LiCOW Paper I) is the first of the series, and gives an overview of the program. There are four more papers that detail the data sets and analysis of the H0LiCOW lens system HE\u00a00435\u22121223. In particular, Sluse et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib144\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib144\" data-open=\"bib144\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>, hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib144\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib144\" data-open=\"bib144\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper II</a>) present the spectroscopic follow-up of the strong-lens field to measure redshifts of massive and nearby objects close in projection to the strong-lens system and identify galaxy groups along the line of sight. Rusu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib134\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib134\" data-open=\"bib134\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>, hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib134\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib134\" data-open=\"bib134\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper III</a>) use our multiband wide-field imaging to characterize the lens environment in combination with ray tracing with numerical simulations. Wong et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib187\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib187\" data-open=\"bib187\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>, hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib187\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib187\" data-open=\"bib187\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper IV</a>) perform the lens mass modelling of the strong-lens system incorporating the time delays, high-resolution imaging and lens stellar kinematics data sets to infer the distance to the lens via blind analysis. Bonvin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>, hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper V</a>) present the time-delay measurements from COSMOGRAIL lens monitoring and the cosmological inference based on the previous three papers.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The outline of this paper is as follows. We describe the key ingredients for time-delay cosmography in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>, present the five H0LiCOW lens systems in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a> and describe our observational campaign in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>. The key components of the four analysis papers introduced above are summarized in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>. We show the forecasted cosmographic constraints from the H0LiCOW sample in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6</a>. We summarize in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec7\"></span><a href=\"#sec7\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">7</a> with an outlook for the program.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=74112286 id=\"74112286\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 OBSERVATIONAL REQUIREMENTS OF THE TIME-DELAY METHOD</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we describe the observational requirements of the four ingredients for accurate and precise distance measurements from time-delay lenses. <ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Time delays</em>. Monitoring campaigns to map out the variability of the multiple lensed images over time have been carried out both in the radio and optical wavelengths (e.g. Vanderriest et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib174\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib174\" data-open=\"bib174\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1989</a>; Schechter et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib135\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib135\" data-open=\"bib135\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>; Burud et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Fassnacht et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Hjorth et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Kochanek et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Vuissoz et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib178\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib178\" data-open=\"bib178\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Rumbaugh et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib132\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib132\" data-open=\"bib132\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Regular and frequent observations, at least once every few days, are necessary so that the variability pattern of the background source can be observed in each of the multiple images and be matched up to obtain the time delays. Monitoring in the optical requires a long baseline or high photometric precision to overcome systematic variations due to microlensing by stars in the lensing galaxy that could be mistaken as the background source intrinsic variability (e.g. Tewes et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib165\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib165\" data-open=\"bib165\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013b</a>; Sluse &amp; Tewes\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib140\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib140\" data-open=\"bib140\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Curve-shifting methods have been developed to measure the time delays from the light curves (e.g. Press, Rybicki &amp; Hewitt\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib122\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib122\" data-open=\"bib122\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1992</a>; Pelt et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib114\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib114\" data-open=\"bib114\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; Fassnacht et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Harva &amp; Raychaudhury\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Morgan et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Hirv, Olspert &amp; Pelt\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Hojjati, Kim &amp; Linder\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Tewes, Courbin &amp; Meylan\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib164\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib164\" data-open=\"bib164\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013a</a>). A recent time-delay challenge showed that some of the methods can recover accurately the time delays in a blind test (Dobler et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Liao et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), particularly the methods we use from the COSMOGRAIL collaboration (e.g. Tewes et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib164\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib164\" data-open=\"bib164\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013a</a>; Bonvin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Well-resolved lensed images</em>. The strong-lensing information, such as the multiple image positions of the background source, is needed to obtain the foreground lens mass distribution for converting the time delays into distances. Deep and high-resolution imaging of the strong-lens system reveal the \u2018Einstein rings\u2019 that are the spatially extended and lensed images of the background source, such as the host galaxy of the AGN. In the past decade, methods have been developed to take advantage of the thousands of intensity pixels of the extended images to constrain precisely within a few percent the lens potential at the location of the multiple images (e.g. Kochanek, Keeton &amp; McLeod\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib82\" data-open=\"bib82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>; Warren &amp; Dye\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib181\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib181\" data-open=\"bib181\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Treu &amp; Koopmans\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib167\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib167\" data-open=\"bib167\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Koopmans\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; Dye et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib156\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib156\" data-open=\"bib156\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Vegetti &amp; Koopmans\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib175\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib175\" data-open=\"bib175\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib160\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib160\" data-open=\"bib160\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Birrer, Amara &amp; Refregier\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Chen et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). The time-delay distance is particularly sensitive to the radial profile of the lens galaxy mass distribution (e.g. Kochanek\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib81\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib81\" data-open=\"bib81\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Wucknitz\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib188\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib188\" data-open=\"bib188\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Wucknitz, Biggs &amp; Browne\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib189\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib189\" data-open=\"bib189\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Suyu\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib154\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib154\" data-open=\"bib154\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Imaging with high-signal-to-noise ratio and high angular resolution of the Einstein ring helps to constrain the lens radial profile in the region of the ring, and hence the time-delay distance, up to a mass-sheet transformation (described below).</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>The lens environment</em>. The distribution of mass external to the lens galaxy, such as that associated with galaxies which are close in projection to the lens system along the line of sight, affects the time delays between the multiple images and hence our cosmological distance measurements. An external convergence \u03ba<sub>ext</sub> can be absorbed by the lens and source model leaving the fit to the lensed images unchanged, but the predicted time delays altered by a factor of (1\u00a0\u2212\u00a0\u03ba<sub>ext</sub>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To break this \u2018mass-sheet degeneracy\u2019 (MSD; Falco, Gorenstein &amp; Shapiro <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1985</a>), one can study the environment of the lens system to constrain \u03ba<sub>ext</sub> within a few percent<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>1</sup></a> through spectroscopic/photometric observations of local galaxy groups and line-of-sight structures (e.g. Fassnacht et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Momcheva et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib97\" data-open=\"bib97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib98\" data-open=\"bib98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) in combination with ray tracing through numerical <em>N</em>-body simulations (e.g. Hilbert et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib157\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib157\" data-open=\"bib157\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Collett et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Greene et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Furthermore, McCully et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) developed a new framework to model line-of-sight mass distributions efficiently and quantified the environment effects through realistic simulations of lens fields. By reconstructing the three-dimensional mass distribution of strong-lens sightlines, McCully et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) can obtain constraints on \u03ba<sub>ext</sub> that are consistent with but tighter than those from the aforementioned statistical approach of combining galaxy number density observations with <em>N</em>-body simulations (see also Collett et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a> whose sightline mass reconstruction also produces tighter constraints on \u03ba<sub>ext</sub> than the statistical approach). Recently, Collett &amp; Cunnington (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) have pointed out that the external convergence over an ensemble of lenses usually does not average to zero \u2013 lenses, like typical massive galaxies, preferentially live in locally overdense regions (Holder &amp; Schechter\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib169\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib169\" data-open=\"bib169\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Fassnacht, Koopmans &amp; Wong <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and are therefore slightly easier to detect and monitor. None the less, this bias in detection and/or selection that is due to overdensity is expected to have currently negligible impact on <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> (&lt;1\u2009per\u2009cent impact). In contrast, measurements of <em>D</em><sub>d</sub> that come from combining delays with the lens velocity dispersion are impervious to \u03ba<sub>ext</sub> (Jee et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>The lens galaxy stellar velocity dispersion</em>. The combination of lensing and stellar kinematics is a powerful probe of the lens galaxy mass distribution (e.g. Romanowsky &amp; Kochanek\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib130\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib130\" data-open=\"bib130\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>; Treu &amp; Koopmans\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib166\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib166\" data-open=\"bib166\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Koopmans et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib86\" data-open=\"bib86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Barnab\u00e8 et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib147\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib147\" data-open=\"bib147\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) since the combination breaks degeneracies that are inherent in each approach, and in particular the mass-sheet degeneracy in lensing. Schneider &amp; Sluse (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib136\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib136\" data-open=\"bib136\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) pointed out that the mass-sheet degeneracy can manifest as a lens mass profile degeneracy, which Xu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib190\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib190\" data-open=\"bib190\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) investigated using simulated galaxies. Moreover, the mass-sheet degeneracy is in fact a special case of a more general \u2018source-position transformation\u2019 (Schneider &amp; Sluse\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib137\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib137\" data-open=\"bib137\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Unruh, Schneider &amp; Sluse\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib172\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib172\" data-open=\"bib172\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), although this latter transformation typically does not leave the multiple time delays invariant. To break such lensing degeneracies, information from the lens galaxy stellar kinematics is crucial: Suyu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib161\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib161\" data-open=\"bib161\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) showed that the lens velocity dispersion substantially reduced the dependence of the time-delay distance on lens mass profile assumptions. The lens velocity dispersion is also a key ingredient for measuring <em>D</em><sub>d</sub>, which is more sensitive to dark energy properties than <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> (Jee et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p></li></ul></p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=74112288 id=\"74112288\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 H0LICOW SAMPLE OF LENSES</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, we show the images of the five lenses in our sample. The left four lenses are quadruply lensed quasar systems (quads) and the rightmost lens system is a doubly lensed quasar system (double). As described below, the four quads span the three generic multiple image configurations we have in galaxy-scale strong lenses: symmetric, fold (with two merging images) and cusp (with three merging images). Therefore, our sample will allow us to explore to some extent the optimal image configuration for cosmographic studies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our sample of lenses was chosen based on three criteria: (1) availability of accurate and precise time delays, (2) existing measurements of spectroscopic redshifts for both the lens and the background source and (3) the lens system is not located near a galaxy cluster (to avoid potentially large systematic effects due to mass along the line of sight). We prefer quads to doubles since quads provide more observational constraints on the mass model (e.g. more time delays and image positions). The four quads in our sample were the only known quad lenses that passed the above three criteria at the time of our sample selection. There were a few doubles that pass these criteria, and we chose HE\u00a01104\u22121805 as the first double in this pilot program given its relative simplicity for mass modelling with only one strong-lens galaxy (in contrast to other systems that have multiple massive lens galaxies). We describe in more detail each of the lenses below.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>B1608+656</em>. The lens system was discovered in the Cosmic Lens All-Sky Survey (Myers et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1995</a>; Browne et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Myers et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>). The radio-loud AGN is lensed into four images that are relatively dim in the optical wavelength, thus showing clearly the extended Einstein ring of the AGN host galaxy in the <em>HST</em> imaging (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). Two of the four multiple images are close together, making this a standard \u2018fold\u2019 configuration. The system contains two lens galaxies that appear to be interacting and resulting in dust extinction in the system (e.g. Koopmans et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib86\" data-open=\"bib86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Surpi &amp; Blandford\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib153\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib153\" data-open=\"bib153\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib156\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib156\" data-open=\"bib156\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). The lens and source redshifts are, respectively, <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.394 (Fassnacht et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>) and <em>z</em><sub>d</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.6304 (Myers et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1995</a>). This system was the first quad lens with all three time delays measured with uncertainties of only a few percent (Fassnacht et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>RXJ1131\u22121231</em>. Sluse et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib141\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib141\" data-open=\"bib141\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) discovered RXJ1131\u22121231 serendipitously during polarimetric imaging of a sample of radio quasars. This system shows a spectacular Einstein ring, with multiple arclets that are the lensed images of the AGN host galaxy containing a bulge and a disk with spiral arms and star formation clumps. Three of the four quasar images are close to each other, forming the typical \u2018cusp\u2019 configuration. The lens redshift is at <em>z</em><sub>d</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.295 (Sluse et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib141\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib141\" data-open=\"bib141\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib142\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib142\" data-open=\"bib142\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>), and the source redshift is at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.654 (Sluse et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib142\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib142\" data-open=\"bib142\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>).<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>2</sup></a></p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>HE\u00a00435\u22121223</em>. This lens system was found by Wisotzki et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib186\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib186\" data-open=\"bib186\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>), originally selected in the Hamburg/ESO survey (Wisotzki et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib185\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib185\" data-open=\"bib185\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>) as a highly probable quasar candidate. The background quasar is lensed into four multiple images that are nearly symmetrically positioned in the \u2018cross\u2019 configuration. The background source is at redshift <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.693 (Sluse et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib143\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib143\" data-open=\"bib143\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>)<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>3</sup></a> and the foreground strong lens is at redshift <em>z</em><sub>d</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.4546 (Morgan et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib102\" data-open=\"bib102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; Eigenbrod et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). The <em>HST</em> image reveals an elliptical ring that connects the four images of the AGN. This ring is produced by the extended lensed images of the AGN galaxy.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>WFI2033\u22124723</em>. Morgan et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) discovered this quad lens system as part of an optical imaging survey using the MPG/ESO 2.2-m telescope at La Silla, Chile that is operated by the European Southern Observatory (ESO). The lens system exhibits a typical fold configuration, since it contains two merging quasar images. The quasar is at redshift <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.662 (Sluse et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib143\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib143\" data-open=\"bib143\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), which is consistent with the first measurement by Morgan et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>). The quasar images are substantially brighter than the background quasar host galaxy and the foreground lens galaxy. Morgan et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) identified the foreground lens galaxy, whose redshift was measured to be <em>z</em><sub>d</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.661 (Eigenbrod et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), consistent with an earlier measurement by Ofek et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib108\" data-open=\"bib108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). The high-resolution <em>HST</em> imaging shows several galaxies in the vicinity of the lens system. Since these galaxies would likely influence the lens potential, their redshifts will be obtained with our ancillary data (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.3</a>) in order to incorporate them into the lens mass model.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>HE\u00a01104\u22121805</em>. This system was also discovered in the early phase of the Hamburg/ESO survey by Wisotzki et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib184\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib184\" data-open=\"bib184\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1993</a>). The two lensed quasar images are separated by \u223c3<sup>\u2033</sup> and is unusual in having the brighter image as the one closer to the foreground lens galaxy, which was first identified by Courbin, Lidman &amp; Magain (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>) and Remy et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib126\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib126\" data-open=\"bib126\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>). The source is at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02.316 (Smette et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib145\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib145\" data-open=\"bib145\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1995</a>), and the lens is at a relatively high redshift of <em>z</em><sub>d</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.729 (Lidman et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib90\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib90\" data-open=\"bib90\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>). The <em>HST</em> image shows multiple luminous structures/galaxies around the lens system.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=74112296 id=\"74112296\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 OBSERVATIONAL FOLLOW-UP</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In collaboration with the COSMOGRAIL team, we carry out an observational campaign in order to obtain each of the four ingredients for distance measurements of the H0LiCOW lenses. We describe the monitoring in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.1</a> to get the time delays, deep <em>HST</em> imaging to constrain the lens galaxy mass distribution in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.2</a>, wide-field spectroscopy and imaging to study the lens environment in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.3</a> and spectroscopy of the foreground lens galaxy to measure the stellar velocity dispersion in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.4</a>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=74112298 id=\"74112298\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 Time delays</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Of the five H0LiCOW lenses, B1608+656 has been monitored previously by Fassnacht et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>) using the Very Large Array, whereas the other four lenses are currently being monitored by the COSMOGRAIL and Kochanek et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) collaborations using a network of 1\u20132\u00a0m optical telescopes, particularly the Euler telescope in Chile.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Using three seasons of monitoring of B1608+656, especially the third season that showed significant variability that repeated in all four quasar images, Fassnacht et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>) measured all three relative time delays between the four quasar images with uncertainties of a few percent. The image fluxes were measured every 3\u20134\u00a0d during the monitoring. The time delays span \u223c30\u201380\u00a0d, relative to the first image that varies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The monitoring of RXJ1131\u22121231, HE\u00a00435\u22121223, WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a01104\u22121805 by the COSMOGRAIL and Kochanek et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) teams started in 2003, with a photometric point every 2\u20134\u00a0d. The MCS deconvolution method (Magain, Courbin &amp; Sohy\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib94\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib94\" data-open=\"bib94\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>; Cantale et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) is used to extract the photometry of the quasar images for building the light curves. Tewes et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib164\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib164\" data-open=\"bib164\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013a</a>) set up an automated pipeline to reduce the images, build the light curves and measure the time delays using a state-of-the-art curve-shifting algorithm that simultaneously models both intrinsic variability of the AGNs and microlensing variations. With this pipeline, Bonvin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) recovered the time delays with a precision of \u223c3\u2009per\u2009cent and negligible bias for simulated light curves mimicking COSMOGRAIL monitoring in the blind strong-lens time delay challenge (Liao et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), demonstrating the robustness of their curve-shifting algorithms.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The monitoring and analysis yield time delays in RXJ1131\u22121231 with a 1.5\u2009per\u2009cent uncertainty on the longest delay (Tewes et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib165\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib165\" data-open=\"bib165\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013b</a>). The light curve has been separately modelled by A. Hojjati and E. Linder using the Gaussian process technique (Hojjati et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), who have obtained delays that are consistent with the measurements of Tewes et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib165\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib165\" data-open=\"bib165\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013b</a>) (Linder, private communication). The monitoring and analysis of HE\u00a00435\u22121223 are described in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper V</a>, with a relative uncertainty of 6.5\u2009per\u2009cent on the longest delay (between images A and D). The measurement precision in the delays has improved by a factor of 2 compared to the previous measurements by Courbin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) with the five additional years of monitoring and improvements in the curve-shifting algorithms. For WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a01104\u22121805, we expect to improve on the previous delay measurements by Vuissoz et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib179\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib179\" data-open=\"bib179\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>) and Poindexter et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib121\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib121\" data-open=\"bib121\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>), respectively, with the new curve-shifting techniques, and estimate relative uncertainties of \u223c4\u2009per\u2009cent and \u223c2\u2009per\u2009cent, respectively, from the monitoring campaign.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=74112303 id=\"74112303\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>4.2 <em>HST</em> observations</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Deep <em>HST</em> Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS) observations of B1608+656 were obtained in Program 10158 (PI: C. D. Fassnacht) in two filters, <em>F</em>606<em>W</em> and <em>F</em>814<em>W</em>. Suyu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib156\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib156\" data-open=\"bib156\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) have described these observations in detail. Furthermore, Suyu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib156\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib156\" data-open=\"bib156\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) analysed these data and used a pixelated lens potential reconstruction technique to model the lens mass distribution, which were subsequently used for cosmographic analysis in Suyu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib157\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib157\" data-open=\"bib157\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Archival <em>HST</em> ACS observations of RXJ1131\u22121231 (Program 9744; PI: C. S. Kochanek) are available in two filters, <em>F</em>555<em>W</em> and <em>F</em>814<em>W</em>. Details of the observations are described in, e.g. Claeskens et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). These have been used to model the lens mass distribution for cosmography, accounting for uncertainties due to assumptions on the lens mass profile (Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib160\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib160\" data-open=\"bib160\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib161\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib161\" data-open=\"bib161\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Recently, Birrer, Amara &amp; Refregier (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) have also used these observations to model independently the lens mass distribution of RXJ1131\u22121231 for cosmography, obtaining results that are consistent with Suyu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib160\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib160\" data-open=\"bib160\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We have obtained new deep <em>HST</em> Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3) observations in Program 12889 (PI: S. H. Suyu) of the remaining three lenses (HE\u00a00435\u22121223, WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a01104\u22121805) in the infrared (IR) channel. The goal of these observations is to detect the Einstein rings of the AGN host galaxies at high signal-to-noise ratios, in order to constrain the foreground lens mass distribution (previous <em>HST</em> observations had insufficient signal-to-noise ratios of the rings for our analysis). We use the <em>F</em>160<em>W</em> filter to optimize the contrast between the AGN host galaxy and the AGN, since the host galaxy is brighter in the IR compared to the optical, especially for HE\u00a01104\u22121805 where the quasar is at a high redshift.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We employ four-point dither patterns that trace out parallelograms with the lengths of the sides being non-integral numbers of pixels. For each lens, we use multiple parallelograms that are offset by non-integral pixels. Specifically, we use 2, 5 and 3 parallelograms for HE\u00a00435\u22121223, WFI2033\u22124723and HE\u00a01104\u22121805, respectively, depending on the total exposure time needed to image the Einstein ring. We further ensure that the dithering points do not overlap to avoid IR persistence effects. This dithering strategy allows us to recover effectively an angular resolution of \u223c0.08arcsec from the native 0.13\u00a0arcsec\u00a0pixel scale.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Since the AGN host galaxy is substantially fainter than the AGN, we further adopt an exposure sequence of short\u2013long\u2013long at each of the dithering point.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>4</sup></a> The first short exposure allows us to characterize the AGN, whereas the long exposures would get the AGN host with possibly the pixels near the bright AGN saturated. We note that there are multiple non-destructive reads during each exposure with the MULTIACCUM mode of the WFC3/IR detector, so we can have a count rate estimate on the AGN pixels even in the long exposures if several non-destructive reads are available before saturation. The short exposures are taken to ensure that there are sufficient reads to characterize accurately the pixel count rates near the AGN positions, in case the long exposures are indeed saturated with insufficient non-destructive reads. In essence, the combination of the short and long exposures allows us to reconstruct in full the brightness distribution of <em>both</em> the lensed AGN and the lensed host galaxy. We summarize our observations in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"74112309\" scrollto-destination=\"74112309\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">New <em>HST</em> WFC3/IR Observations of HE\u00a00435\u22121223, WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a01104\u22121805.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Lens<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n At each dither position, an exposure sequence of short\u2013long\u2013long exposure times is adopted in order to sample the large dynamical range of the AGN and its much fainter host galaxy.<sup>4</sup></p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/74112309\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" and HE\u00a01104\u22121805.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Lens<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Date<span .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>HE\u00a00435\u22121223\u00a0</td><td>2012-10-28\u00a0</td><td>8 short exp.\u00a0</td><td>44\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>15 long exp.<sup>4</sup>\u00a0</td><td>599\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WFI2033\u22124723\u00a0</td><td>2013-05-03\u00a0</td><td>20 short exp.\u00a0</td><td>74\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>to 2013-05-04\u00a0</td><td>4 long exp.<sup>4</sup>\u00a0</td><td>599\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>32 long exp.<sup>4</sup>\u00a0</td><td>699\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HE\u00a01104\u22121805\u00a0</td><td>2013-03-18\u00a0</td><td>12 short exp.\u00a0</td><td>26\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>24 long exp.\u00a0</td><td>599\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Lens<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Date<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Number/type<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Time (s) per<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>of exposures<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>exposure<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>HE\u00a00435\u22121223\u00a0</td><td>2012-10-28\u00a0</td><td>8 short exp.\u00a0</td><td>44\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>15 long exp.<sup>4</sup>\u00a0</td><td>599\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WFI2033\u22124723\u00a0</td><td>2013-05-03\u00a0</td><td>20 short exp.\u00a0</td><td>74\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>to 2013-05-04\u00a0</td><td>4 long exp.<sup>4</sup>\u00a0</td><td>599\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>32 long exp.<sup>4</sup>\u00a0</td><td>699\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HE\u00a01104\u22121805\u00a0</td><td>2013-03-18\u00a0</td><td>12 short exp.\u00a0</td><td>26\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>24 long exp.\u00a0</td><td>599\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN001\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN001\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>. At each dither position, an exposure sequence of short\u2013long\u2013long exposure times is adopted in order to sample the large dynamical range of the AGN and its much fainter host galaxy.<sup>4</sup></p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/74112309\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We reduce the images using <span class=\"small-caps\">DrizzlePac</span>.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn5\" data-open=\"fn5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>5</sup></a> The images are drizzled to a final pixel scale of 0.08 arcsec, without masking the bright AGN pixels as they are well characterized by the short exposures. The uncertainty on the flux in each pixel is estimated from the science image and the drizzled exposure time map by adding in quadrature the Poisson noise from the source and the background noise due to the sky and detector readout.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, we show the reduced <em>HST</em> WFC3 observations of HE\u00a00435\u22121223, WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a00435\u22121223 in the top panels from left to right. In the bottom, we show the images with the lens light subtracted with <span class=\"small-caps\">glee</span>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn6\" data-open=\"fn6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>6</sup></a> revealing the Einstein ring of the AGN host galaxy. In <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib187\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib187\" data-open=\"bib187\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper IV</a>, we detail the modelling of HE\u00a00435\u22121223 using multilens-plane ray tracing (e.g. Blandford &amp; Narayan\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1986</a>; Schneider et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib138\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib138\" data-open=\"bib138\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1992</a>; Blandford &amp; Kochanek\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) and point spread function (PSF) reconstruction techniques developed by Suyu et\u00a0al. (in preparation). The subtraction of lens light in WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a01104\u22121805 (bottom-middle and bottom-right panels of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, respectively) is based on an initial PSF built from stars in the field without any lens mass modelling or iterative PSF reconstruction, hence the lens-subtraction residuals. Furthermore, the lens galaxy of HE\u00a01104\u22121805 is on a diffraction spike of the brighter AGN image \u2013 an accurate PSF model would be crucial for distinguishing the lens galaxy, the two AGN images and the lensed host galaxy of the AGN. The full modelling and analysis of WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a01104\u22121805 will appear in future publications.</p>                        <a id=\"74112312\" scrollto-destination=\"74112312\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/468/3/10.1093_mnras_stx483/1/m_stx483fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611466631&amp;Signature=vcQX7HAyabEEYj2B4bJgylkjUxDfa7E0FOPRg9O259UROajboXWPYlGoegN7tJmONoF4nEOSs-6iWJEl5EHjU-gHu4T65aSDKuh0wpQimAkDyW5kosdXz-c4a4KrbZlzw-843Ncaog~5JPN29KB9jTr2-PlLqwgO4HW6~E9sKJXgFAoG0spA4Ot15gN1ydvvx4RPK2tlkwMLCNMBTR8B~OeBeFbBPAZErgeympbfvL1ZOnsl6r1HC7AFsQw2rD2WECFZnzXAzFRIfwD0SedAzF1lfZFkGzS6jjG7we1-ptdntJWK6SWL3~dQPGJGUIxof~bQF3tFruM9it3bB-el3A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"HST WFC3 F160W observation of HE\u00a00435\u22121223, WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a01104\u22121805 from left to right in the top panels. In the bottom panels, the lens-galaxy light has been subtracted, revealing the Einstein ring of the AGN host galaxy that is needed for accurate and precise lens mass modelling. The full modelling of HE\u00a00435\u22121223 is detailed in H0LiCOW Paper IV. The lens subtraction for WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a01104\u22121805 in the bottom-middle and bottom-right panels, respectively, is based on an initial PSF model without PSF reconstruction (which we defer to future work), hence the visible residuals. In each of the panels, north is up and east is left.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx483fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/74112312/stx483fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx483fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"74112312\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/468/3/10.1093_mnras_stx483/1/stx483fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611466631&Signature=EW9bYdGwq~YXUDo28DbhdwSitvpuu-G~9YYiwGqIwvhd04leoIOuO38ka5QENVq6Z-jC~Emb7xBeUjfR6mcHvJ~RoTSxYkyceKx~grKCtAzBq8qc1OSPLh6N1UFv3EGxTJFx0inHwr1aOAiN7xRqq63whjF06-vi7jIV3xGaYuJaytZlhu9JL2M3TpkB3KaKZSmcgoyJd71-lHCCXGDrVFQ1vu2tB4GegUgsMYocH4h02xamTJ7ha28iJRCjijvFGMu371RVop7Mt4jKx8PAFskxDPuAKg5YesPuqGuJ6IuGYCPuHyV6aqkMejngFzI2ot9MnxN~-0IDIZhJ6JbNuQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=74112312&ar=3055701&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx483fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>HST</em> WFC3 <em>F</em>160<em>W</em> observation of HE\u00a00435\u22121223, WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a01104\u22121805 from left to right in the top panels. In the bottom panels, the lens-galaxy light has been subtracted, revealing the Einstein ring of the AGN host galaxy that is needed for accurate and precise lens mass modelling. The full modelling of HE\u00a00435\u22121223 is detailed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib187\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib187\" data-open=\"bib187\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper IV</a>. The lens subtraction for WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a01104\u22121805 in the bottom-middle and bottom-right panels, respectively, is based on an initial PSF model without PSF reconstruction (which we defer to future work), hence the visible residuals. In each of the panels, north is up and east is left.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/468/3/10.1093_mnras_stx483/1/m_stx483fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611466631&amp;Signature=vcQX7HAyabEEYj2B4bJgylkjUxDfa7E0FOPRg9O259UROajboXWPYlGoegN7tJmONoF4nEOSs-6iWJEl5EHjU-gHu4T65aSDKuh0wpQimAkDyW5kosdXz-c4a4KrbZlzw-843Ncaog~5JPN29KB9jTr2-PlLqwgO4HW6~E9sKJXgFAoG0spA4Ot15gN1ydvvx4RPK2tlkwMLCNMBTR8B~OeBeFbBPAZErgeympbfvL1ZOnsl6r1HC7AFsQw2rD2WECFZnzXAzFRIfwD0SedAzF1lfZFkGzS6jjG7we1-ptdntJWK6SWL3~dQPGJGUIxof~bQF3tFruM9it3bB-el3A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"HST WFC3 F160W observation of HE\u00a00435\u22121223, WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a01104\u22121805 from left to right in the top panels. In the bottom panels, the lens-galaxy light has been subtracted, revealing the Einstein ring of the AGN host galaxy that is needed for accurate and precise lens mass modelling. The full modelling of HE\u00a00435\u22121223 is detailed in H0LiCOW Paper IV. The lens subtraction for WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a01104\u22121805 in the bottom-middle and bottom-right panels, respectively, is based on an initial PSF model without PSF reconstruction (which we defer to future work), hence the visible residuals. In each of the panels, north is up and east is left.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx483fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/74112312/stx483fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx483fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"74112312\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/468/3/10.1093_mnras_stx483/1/stx483fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611466631&Signature=EW9bYdGwq~YXUDo28DbhdwSitvpuu-G~9YYiwGqIwvhd04leoIOuO38ka5QENVq6Z-jC~Emb7xBeUjfR6mcHvJ~RoTSxYkyceKx~grKCtAzBq8qc1OSPLh6N1UFv3EGxTJFx0inHwr1aOAiN7xRqq63whjF06-vi7jIV3xGaYuJaytZlhu9JL2M3TpkB3KaKZSmcgoyJd71-lHCCXGDrVFQ1vu2tB4GegUgsMYocH4h02xamTJ7ha28iJRCjijvFGMu371RVop7Mt4jKx8PAFskxDPuAKg5YesPuqGuJ6IuGYCPuHyV6aqkMejngFzI2ot9MnxN~-0IDIZhJ6JbNuQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=74112312&ar=3055701&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx483fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>HST</em> WFC3 <em>F</em>160<em>W</em> observation of HE\u00a00435\u22121223, WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a01104\u22121805 from left to right in the top panels. In the bottom panels, the lens-galaxy light has been subtracted, revealing the Einstein ring of the AGN host galaxy that is needed for accurate and precise lens mass modelling. The full modelling of HE\u00a00435\u22121223 is detailed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib187\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib187\" data-open=\"bib187\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper IV</a>. The lens subtraction for WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a01104\u22121805 in the bottom-middle and bottom-right panels, respectively, is based on an initial PSF model without PSF reconstruction (which we defer to future work), hence the visible residuals. In each of the panels, north is up and east is left.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=74112313 id=\"74112313\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3>4.3 Wide-field spectroscopy and imaging of lens environment</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We obtain wide-field spectroscopy to pinpoint the redshifts of the bright galaxies in the fields of the H0LiCOW lenses, particularly the ones close to the strong lens. Redshifts of nearby galaxies, especially those within a few arcseconds from the strong lens, are crucial since the external convergence approximation is often insufficient for these galaxies (e.g. McCully et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) and they need to be incorporated directly into the strong-lens modelling. We use the multiobject spectrographs on the Very Large Telescope, the Gemini Telescope and the W. M. Keck Telescope to target our lens fields, as summarized in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. The spectroscopic redshifts and galaxy group identifications are detailed in Fassnacht et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib144\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib144\" data-open=\"bib144\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper II</a>, and forthcoming publications.</p>                        <a id=\"74112315\" scrollto-destination=\"74112315\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Wide-field spectroscopy of H0LiCOW lenses as part of the H0LiCOW program.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Lens<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Facility/instrument<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Proposal PI<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>B1608+656\u00a0</td><td>W. Abbreviations are LRIS (Low-Resolution Imaging Spectrometer; Oke et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib112\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib112\" data-open=\"bib112\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1995</a>; Rockosi et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib129\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib129\" data-open=\"bib129\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), ESI (Echellete Spectrograph and Imager; Sheinis et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib139\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib139\" data-open=\"bib139\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>), VLT (Very Large Telescope), FORS2 (FOcal Reducer and low dispersion Spectrograph; Appenzeller et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>) and GMOS (Gemini Multi-Object Spectrographs; Hook et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>). Details of the observations for B1608+656 are in Fassnacht et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), and for the other four lenses are in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib144\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib144\" data-open=\"bib144\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper II</a> and forthcoming publications. Additional integral field spectroscopy of the central 30 arcmin around WFI2033\u22124723 has been recently obtained with the Multi Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE; Bacon et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) on the VLT.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/74112315\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">To further characterize the lens environment and determine \u03ba<sub>ext</sub>, we obtain wide-field multiband imaging using the Canada\u2013France\u2013Hawaii Telescope, Subaru Telescope, the Very Large Telescope, Gemini Telescope and <em>Spitzer Space Telescope</em>. Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> summarizes the follow-up imaging that allow us to compute the photometric redshifts of structures along the line of sight as well as to estimate their stellar masses. Details of the observations and inference on \u03ba<sub>ext</sub> are described in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib134\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib134\" data-open=\"bib134\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper III</a> and forthcoming publications.</p>                        <a id=\"74112317\" scrollto-destination=\"74112317\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl3\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Wide-field imaging obtained as part of the H0LiCOW program.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Lens<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Facility/instrument<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Wavelength bands<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Proposal PI<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>B1608+656\u00a0</td><td>CFHT/MegaCam\u00a0</td><td><em>u</em>\u00a0</td><td>S. Abbreviations and references for the instruments are CFHT (Canada\u2013France\u2013Hawaii Telescope) MegaCam (Boulade et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>), Suprime-Cam (Miyazaki et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib96\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib96\" data-open=\"bib96\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>), MOIRCS (Multi-Object InfraRed Camera and Spectrograph; Suzuki et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib162\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib162\" data-open=\"bib162\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Ichikawa et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), NIRI (Near InfraRed Imager and Spectrometer; Hodapp et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>), IRAC (Infrared Array Camera; Fazio et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>), CTIO (Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory) DECam (Dark Energy Camera; Diehl &amp; Dark Energy Survey Collaboration\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), VLT (Very Large Telescope) HAWK-I (High Acuity Wide field K-band Imager; Pirard et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib118\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib118\" data-open=\"bib118\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Casali et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Kissler-Patig et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). Details of the observations are in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib134\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib134\" data-open=\"bib134\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper III</a> and forthcoming publications. WFI2033\u22124723 is in the footprint of the Dark Energy Survey with observations in <em>g</em>, <em>r</em>, <em>i</em>, <em>z</em> and <em>Y</em> bands, so we did not target WFI2033\u22124723 in these bands. We observed only B1608+656 with <em>Spitzer</em> since the other four lenses have archival <em>Spitzer</em>/IRAC observations (PI: C. S. Kochanek).</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/74112317\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Williams et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib183\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib183\" data-open=\"bib183\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) have independently obtained <em>I</em> and either <em>V</em> or <em>R</em> images of all five H0LiCOW lenses using the 4-m Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory (CTIO) Blanco telescope for the southern fields and the 4-m Kitt Peak National Observatory Mayall telescope for the northern fields. Using these images to select spectroscopic targets, Momcheva et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib98\" data-open=\"bib98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) have obtained spectroscopic observations of the five H0LiCOW lenses using the 6.5-m Magellan telescopes. In <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib144\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib144\" data-open=\"bib144\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper II</a>, we merge the spectroscopic catalogue from the multiple spectroscopic campaigns on HE\u00a00435\u22121223.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=74112319 id=\"74112319\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-4>4.4 Lens galaxy spectroscopy for lens velocity dispersion</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">For B1608+656 and RXJ1131\u22121231, we have obtained long-slit spectra of the lens systems with the Low-Resolution Imaging Spectrometer (LRIS; Oke et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib112\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib112\" data-open=\"bib112\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1995</a>) at the Keck Observatory for measuring the lens stellar velocity dispersion (Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib157\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib157\" data-open=\"bib157\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib160\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib160\" data-open=\"bib160\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). For HE\u00a00435\u22121223, we observe the lens system with LRIS in multiobject mode to obtain spectra of the foreground lens galaxy for lens velocity dispersion measurement (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib187\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib187\" data-open=\"bib187\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper IV</a>) and also of nearby galaxies (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib144\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib144\" data-open=\"bib144\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper II</a>). Both WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a01104\u22121805 have bright AGNs relative to the lens galaxy, making the lens velocity dispersion measurement challenging. We have new observations of WFI2033\u22124723 with MUSE (Bacon et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) at the VLT, which we expect will allow us to reduce the uncertainty on the current lens velocity dispersion by a factor of 2, to \u223c5\u20137\u2009per\u2009cent precision. The velocity dispersion is a key ingredient to break the MSD/lensing degeneracies (e.g. Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib161\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib161\" data-open=\"bib161\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). For HE\u00a01104\u22121805, we obtained one-sixth of our proposed observations with XSHOOTER on the VLT in priority B, which is not sufficient to measure the velocity dispersion. We have time on OSIRIS (OH-Suppressing Infra-Red Imaging Spectrograph; Larkin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) on Keck to observe HE\u00a01104\u22121805, RXJ1131\u22121231and HE\u00a00435\u22121223 with adaptive optics. Because OSIRIS is an integral field spectrograph, these observations have the goal of obtaining two-dimensional kinematic data of the foreground lens, which will then be used to further constrain the lens mass models. We summarize the spectroscopic observations for lens velocity dispersion measurement in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"74112321\" scrollto-destination=\"74112321\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl4\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl4\" data-id=\"tbl4\"><span class=\"label\">Table 4.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Spectroscopy of foreground lens as part of the H0LiCOW program.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Lens<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Facility/instrument<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Proposal PI<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>B1608+656\u00a0</td><td>W. Keck/OSIRIS\u00a0</td><td>T. Treu\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HE\u00a00435\u22121223\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/LRIS\u00a0</td><td>C. D. Fassnacht\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>W. M.
