Treu\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN004\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN004\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>. OSIRIS is the OH-Suppressing Infra-Red Imaging Spectrograph (Larkin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). Details of the LRIS observations for B1608+656 are in Suyu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib157\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib157\" data-open=\"bib157\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), for RXJ1131\u22121231 are in Suyu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib160\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib160\" data-open=\"bib160\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), and for HE\u00a00435\u22121223 are in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib187\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib187\" data-open=\"bib187\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper IV</a>; other observations are in forthcoming publications. Only one-sixth of the HE\u00a01104\u22121805 observations with X-shooter (Vernet et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib176\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib176\" data-open=\"bib176\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) were obtained, which were insufficient for measuring the lens velocity dispersion. The observations with OSIRIS are pending.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/74112321\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl4\" data-id=\"tbl4\"><span class=\"label\">Table 4.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Spectroscopy of foreground lens as part of the H0LiCOW program.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Lens<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Facility/instrument<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Proposal PI<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>B1608+656\u00a0</td><td>W. Treu\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Lens<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Facility/instrument<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Proposal PI<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>B1608+656\u00a0</td><td>W. Keck/OSIRIS\u00a0</td><td>T. Treu\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HE\u00a00435\u22121223\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/LRIS\u00a0</td><td>C. D. Fassnacht\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/OSIRIS\u00a0</td><td>T. Treu\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>WFI2033\u22124723\u00a0</td><td>VLT/MUSE\u00a0</td><td>D. Sluse\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HE\u00a01104\u22121805\u00a0</td><td>VLT/X-shooter\u00a0</td><td>C. Spiniello\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>W. M. Keck/OSIRIS\u00a0</td><td>T. Treu\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN004\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN004\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>. OSIRIS is the OH-Suppressing Infra-Red Imaging Spectrograph (Larkin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). Details of the LRIS observations for B1608+656 are in Suyu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib157\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib157\" data-open=\"bib157\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), for RXJ1131\u22121231 are in Suyu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib160\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib160\" data-open=\"bib160\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), and for HE\u00a00435\u22121223 are in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib187\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib187\" data-open=\"bib187\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper IV</a>; other observations are in forthcoming publications. Only one-sixth of the HE\u00a01104\u22121805 observations with X-shooter (Vernet et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib176\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib176\" data-open=\"bib176\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) were obtained, which were insufficient for measuring the lens velocity dispersion. The observations with OSIRIS are pending.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/74112321\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=74112322 id=\"74112322\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 COSMOGRAPHY AND ASTROPHYSICS WITH HE\u00a00435\u22121223: KEY COMPONENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We summarize the key ingredients and analysis of HE\u00a00435\u22121223 that are described in upcoming publications of the H0LiCOW project (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib144\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib144\" data-open=\"bib144\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Papers II</a>\u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">V</a>). The titles of the papers begin with \u2018H0LiCOW\u2019, followed by the specific titles written below.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">II. Spectroscopic survey and galaxy-group identification of the strong gravitational lens systems HE\u00a00435\u22121223 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib144\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib144\" data-open=\"bib144\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper II</a>). From our spectroscopic campaign of the lens environment, we present the measured spectroscopic redshifts, focusing in particular on the massive and nearby objects to the strong-lens system that are necessary ingredients for lens mass modelling and distance measurement. By combining with the spectroscopic catalogue of independent efforts (Momcheva et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib98\" data-open=\"bib98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), we identify potential galaxy groups towards HE\u00a00435\u22121223 in order to control the systematic effect due to the galaxies along the line of sight. We use the flexion shift<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn7\" data-open=\"fn7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>7</sup></a> introduced by McCully et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) to determine which mass structures (galaxies/groups) need to be incorporated explicitly in the lens mass model and which could be well approximated by an external shear/convergence field. The flexion-shift analysis presented in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib144\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib144\" data-open=\"bib144\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper II</a> shows that the most significant line-of-sight perturber is the galaxy G1 that is closest to the lens system, which justifies our inclusion of this particular galaxy in all of our strong-lensing models in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib187\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib187\" data-open=\"bib187\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper IV</a>. Furthermore, the next four nearest perturbers from the lens system may also produce higher order perturbations on the lens potential, and we account for the effects of these four additional galaxies in one of our systematic tests in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib187\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib187\" data-open=\"bib187\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper IV</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">III. Quantifying the effect of mass along the line of sight to the gravitational lens HE\u00a00435\u22121223 through weighted galaxy counts (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib134\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib134\" data-open=\"bib134\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper III</a>). Using the wide-field photometry and spectroscopy in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.3</a>, we compute photometric redshifts and stellar masses for objects in the field up to 120 arcsec from the strong lens, and with <em>i</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a024\u00a0mag. We thoroughly test the weighted galaxy number counts technique of Greene et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), and apply it to HE\u00a00435\u22121223 with the CFHTLenS survey (Heymans et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) as the control field. By comparing the weighted counts to simulated lines of sight that are ray traced through numerical simulations (Hilbert et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>), we infer the distribution for the external convergence \u03ba<sub>ext</sub> that excludes the strong-lens redshift plane.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">IV. Lens mass model of HE\u00a00435\u22121223 and blind measurement of its time-delay distance for cosmology (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib187\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib187\" data-open=\"bib187\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper IV</a>). Using the time delays from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper V</a> and our <em>HST</em>/WFC3-IR imaging (<em>F</em>160<em>W</em>) and archival <em>HST</em>/ACS observations (<em>F</em>555<em>W</em> and <em>F</em>814<em>W</em>), we model the lens mass distribution including explicitly the nearest, in projection from HE\u00a00435\u22121223, one (G1) or five (G1 plus the next four nearest/brightest) perturbers, with spectroscopic redshifts from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib144\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib144\" data-open=\"bib144\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper II</a>. We then incorporate the velocity dispersion of the lens galaxy, and the external convergence distribution from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib134\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib134\" data-open=\"bib134\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper III</a> to infer an effective time-delay distance, which is blinded during the analysis stage. We unblind only after the completion of the analysis, and publish these results without modifications.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">V. New COSMOGRAIL time delays of HE\u00a00435\u22121223: <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> to 3.8\u00a0per\u00a0cent from strong lensing in flat-\u039bCDM (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper V</a>). We present the 13-yr monitoring of HE\u00a00435\u22121223 and measure the time delays between the image pairs. Using the resulting effective time-delay distance of HE\u00a00435\u22121223 from the blind analysis in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib187\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib187\" data-open=\"bib187\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper IV</a>, we create a Time Delay Strong Lensing (TDSL) probe with HE\u00a00435\u22121223, RXJ1131\u22121231 and B1608+656 (we note that the analysis of RXJ1131\u22121231 was also blinded in Suyu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib160\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib160\" data-open=\"bib160\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), whereas the analysis of B1608+656 was not as it was the first lens to be analysed using our modelling techniques). We infer cosmological constraints from TDSL alone, and combine it with other cosmological probes to constrain various cosmological models.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition to the above, there are more forthcoming publications. The study of the AGN host galaxy properties based on simulations are described in H0LiCOW Paper VI (Ding et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). The newly developed multilens plane modelling, based on the multilens plane equations (Schneider et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib138\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib138\" data-open=\"bib138\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1992</a>; Blandford &amp; Kochanek\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>), and PSF reconstruction will be detailed by Suyu et\u00a0al. (in preparation). The weak-lensing analysis of the field of HE\u00a00435\u22121223 will be presented by Tihhonova et\u00a0al. (in preparation). Following these publications, there will be the next studies and analysis of the remaining sample (WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a01104\u22121805).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=74112329 id=\"74112329\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>6 H0LICOW COSMOGRAPHIC FORECAST</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We make predictions of the cosmographic constraints based on our sample of H0LiCOW lenses. We use the time-delay distance measurements for B1608+656 (equation 35 of Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib157\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib157\" data-open=\"bib157\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), RXJ1131\u22121231 (equation 5 of Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib161\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib161\" data-open=\"bib161\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) and HE\u00a00435\u22121223 (equation 17 of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib187\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib187\" data-open=\"bib187\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper IV</a>). For the forecasted time-delay distance measurements of the other two lenses, we adopt an uncertainty with contributions from the time delays, mass modelling and external convergence added in quadrature. Specifically, we estimate time-delay uncertainties of 4\u2009per\u2009cent and 2\u2009per\u2009cent, modelling uncertainties of 4\u2009per\u2009cent and 8\u2009per\u2009cent, external convergence uncertainties of 4\u2009per\u2009cent and 4\u2009per\u2009cent, yielding a total uncertainty of 7\u2009per\u2009cent and 9\u2009per\u2009cent for WFI2033\u22124723 and HE\u00a01104\u22121805, respectively. Furthermore, we assume that the angular diameter distance to each lens can be measured with an uncertainty of 15\u2009per\u2009cent using our current data sets (Jee et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). More precise measurements of <em>D</em><sub>d</sub> (\u223c5\u201310\u2009per\u2009cent uncertainty) would require additional kinematic data of the lens galaxy beyond what we currently have, particularly spatially resolved kinematics maps. For the forecasted <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> and <em>D</em><sub>d</sub> constraints, we adopt a fiducial cosmological model with <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = 72\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u2212 1</sup>, \u03a9<sub>m</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01\u00a0\u2212\u00a0\u03a9<sub>DE</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.32, and <em>w</em>\u00a0=\u00a0\u22121 to predict the distances with their estimated uncertainties mentioned above, although we note that this assumption affects little the fractional uncertainty, which is nearly scale-free.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We show in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, the cosmographic constraints of our sample of lenses with uniform priors on the cosmological parameters (left-column panels), in combination with <em>WMAP</em> 9-yr results (Hinshaw et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>, middle-left-column panels), and in combination with <em>Planck</em> 2015 results (Planck Collaboration XIII\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib120\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib120\" data-open=\"bib120\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>, middle-right-column panels)<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn8\" data-open=\"fn8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>8</sup></a> for three different background cosmologies: (1) open \u039bCDM with variable spatial curvature \u03a9<sub>k</sub> (top row), (2) spatially flat <em>w</em>CDM with <em>w</em> as the time-independent dark energy equation of state (middle row) and (3) flat \u039bCDM with varying effective number of relativistic species <em>N</em><sub>eff</sub> (bottom row). In the right-column panels, we show the one-dimensional marginalized constraints of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> of our sample of lenses alone or in combination with the CMB data sets (i.e. marginalized <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> distributions of the panels to the left), as indicated in the legend. We list in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> the prior ranges for the uniform background cosmologies. The <em>WMAP</em> 9-yr and <em>Planck</em> chains have a prior with <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> &lt; 100\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u2212 1</sup> imposed. The cosmographic constraints of our lenses shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> (from the forecasted measurements of <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> and <em>D</em><sub>d</sub>) mostly stem from the <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> measurements as a results of the substantially smaller uncertainties of <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> than that of <em>D</em><sub>d</sub>. In fact, the cosmographic constraints from <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> alone would increase the <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> 1\u03c3 uncertainties shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> by at most 0.8\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u2212 1</sup> (depending on the background cosmology). The additional cosmographic information from <em>D</em><sub>d</sub> would become more significant when the <em>D</em><sub>d</sub> uncertainties are reduced to \u223c5\u201310\u2009per\u2009cent (Jee et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"74112332\" scrollto-destination=\"74112332\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/468/3/10.1093_mnras_stx483/1/m_stx483fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466631&amp;Signature=l2IX7FIAJm9-ZiNbHleqHUhokOpMsOgLRlKi21c66YpF7dA~wesxLjInfqfOcbffkj8ZgoNeOrP0tNjxzqCGBWzYx358s5JBtNzPNLK9ZkaTqyGsuPYTGWhkjp0dbx3OGMwaUROcSPpTz~aRzQZAh2XS5KTK7m4Wl2nE0k~nIuLscDMfBq7jNLEESXIJuUK4In2VzGsD4yBDXAionpMrC1gCIOAhy8OQeE2PSemO3Oej9W40UsTNMDdxVE9WQonU43~Rau1S8ilBlXWmpJUchLTAsZTze5TOdqlslrduTVPN26IHilIr46ckXO0uaSnu1nKo-0rBK-Z-Y0jSwfIvsA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Forecasted cosmographic constraints from the H0LiCOW lens sample through measurements of D\u0394t and Dd. Columns from left to right are, respectively, the constraints from the H0LiCOW lenses alone (with uniform prior on cosmological parameters), lenses in combination with WMAP 9-yr results, lenses in combination with Planck 2015 results, and marginalized constraints on H0 from the previous three columns. The H0LiCOW lenses primarily constrain H0, which in turn break CMB parameter degeneracies to elucidate the spatial curvature of universe (\u03a9k, top row), dark energy equation of state (w, middle row) and effective number of relativistic species (Neff, bottom row). H0LiCOW lenses provide an independent, complementary and competitive probe of cosmology.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx483fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/74112332/stx483fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx483fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"74112332\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/468/3/10.1093_mnras_stx483/1/stx483fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466631&Signature=xYUpz5AhLVuIgduS3uzgjGre5G-4C8rh5kefT9CM-rgIdPTK7bNXUNgdtZM3L2EYTmoQYo6PqD8oCjBaNFnM2Bo2L96DGoY31YnXSTEw3r81QmS5jdUpFw~J5z2CAkw2~SWF5RnE3lG30~LCDf9h3vVxpFWph2cklTlm5TrwUK0IluzYgMLSDMkTw5q2vrCYtL-AAxHOFg-QpbNW1xC0Wd8Kit9KW8K2VhGtO45~mnPPbroOWG42MadDb6cHR~oPliMoYvxj-gl3WN7UtCt8xABVv3~s9vgbyIRXRTurjcjk~30MMvfrdv~Qreqk95OwSpNMINWHDULRrq00KrY3NQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=74112332&ar=3055701&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx483fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Forecasted cosmographic constraints from the H0LiCOW lens sample through measurements of <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> and <em>D</em><sub>d</sub>. Columns from left to right are, respectively, the constraints from the H0LiCOW lenses alone (with uniform prior on cosmological parameters), lenses in combination with <em>WMAP</em> 9-yr results, lenses in combination with <em>Planck</em> 2015 results, and marginalized constraints on <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> from the previous three columns. The H0LiCOW lenses primarily constrain <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>, which in turn break CMB parameter degeneracies to elucidate the spatial curvature of universe (\u03a9<sub>k</sub>, top row), dark energy equation of state (<em>w</em>, middle row) and effective number of relativistic species (<em>N</em><sub>eff</sub>, bottom row). H0LiCOW lenses provide an independent, complementary and competitive probe of cosmology.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/468/3/10.1093_mnras_stx483/1/m_stx483fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466631&amp;Signature=l2IX7FIAJm9-ZiNbHleqHUhokOpMsOgLRlKi21c66YpF7dA~wesxLjInfqfOcbffkj8ZgoNeOrP0tNjxzqCGBWzYx358s5JBtNzPNLK9ZkaTqyGsuPYTGWhkjp0dbx3OGMwaUROcSPpTz~aRzQZAh2XS5KTK7m4Wl2nE0k~nIuLscDMfBq7jNLEESXIJuUK4In2VzGsD4yBDXAionpMrC1gCIOAhy8OQeE2PSemO3Oej9W40UsTNMDdxVE9WQonU43~Rau1S8ilBlXWmpJUchLTAsZTze5TOdqlslrduTVPN26IHilIr46ckXO0uaSnu1nKo-0rBK-Z-Y0jSwfIvsA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Forecasted cosmographic constraints from the H0LiCOW lens sample through measurements of D\u0394t and Dd. Columns from left to right are, respectively, the constraints from the H0LiCOW lenses alone (with uniform prior on cosmological parameters), lenses in combination with WMAP 9-yr results, lenses in combination with Planck 2015 results, and marginalized constraints on H0 from the previous three columns. The H0LiCOW lenses primarily constrain H0, which in turn break CMB parameter degeneracies to elucidate the spatial curvature of universe (\u03a9k, top row), dark energy equation of state (w, middle row) and effective number of relativistic species (Neff, bottom row). H0LiCOW lenses provide an independent, complementary and competitive probe of cosmology.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx483fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/74112332/stx483fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx483fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"74112332\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/468/3/10.1093_mnras_stx483/1/stx483fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466631&Signature=xYUpz5AhLVuIgduS3uzgjGre5G-4C8rh5kefT9CM-rgIdPTK7bNXUNgdtZM3L2EYTmoQYo6PqD8oCjBaNFnM2Bo2L96DGoY31YnXSTEw3r81QmS5jdUpFw~J5z2CAkw2~SWF5RnE3lG30~LCDf9h3vVxpFWph2cklTlm5TrwUK0IluzYgMLSDMkTw5q2vrCYtL-AAxHOFg-QpbNW1xC0Wd8Kit9KW8K2VhGtO45~mnPPbroOWG42MadDb6cHR~oPliMoYvxj-gl3WN7UtCt8xABVv3~s9vgbyIRXRTurjcjk~30MMvfrdv~Qreqk95OwSpNMINWHDULRrq00KrY3NQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=74112332&ar=3055701&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx483fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Forecasted cosmographic constraints from the H0LiCOW lens sample through measurements of <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> and <em>D</em><sub>d</sub>. Columns from left to right are, respectively, the constraints from the H0LiCOW lenses alone (with uniform prior on cosmological parameters), lenses in combination with <em>WMAP</em> 9-yr results, lenses in combination with <em>Planck</em> 2015 results, and marginalized constraints on <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> from the previous three columns. The H0LiCOW lenses primarily constrain <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>, which in turn break CMB parameter degeneracies to elucidate the spatial curvature of universe (\u03a9<sub>k</sub>, top row), dark energy equation of state (<em>w</em>, middle row) and effective number of relativistic species (<em>N</em><sub>eff</sub>, bottom row). H0LiCOW lenses provide an independent, complementary and competitive probe of cosmology.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"74112333\" scrollto-destination=\"74112333\"></a>\r\n<div 10]\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Cosmology<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Prior ranges<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Open \u039bCDM\u00a0</td><td><em>H</em><sub>0</sub> \u2208 [0, 120]\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u03a9<sub>m</sub> \u2208 [0, 0.5]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub> \u2208 [0.5, 1]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u03a9<sub>k</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01\u00a0\u2212\u00a0\u03a9<sub>m</sub>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0\u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Flat <em>w</em>CDM\u00a0</td><td><em>H</em><sub>0</sub> \u2208 [0, 120]\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u03a9<sub>m</sub> \u2208 [0, 1]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u03a9<sub>DE</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01\u00a0\u2212\u00a0\u03a9<sub>m</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td><em>w</em> \u2208 [\u22122.5, 0]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Flat <em>N</em><sub>eff</sub>\u039bCDM\u00a0</td><td><em>H</em><sub>0</sub> \u2208 [0, 120]\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u03a9<sub>m</sub> \u2208 [0, 1]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01\u00a0\u2212\u00a0\u03a9<sub>m</sub>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td><em>N</em><sub>eff</sub> \u2208 [0, 10]\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/74112333\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">As seen in the left column, the time-delay lenses primarily constrain <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>, and depend weakly (if at all) on other parameters. None the less, the time-delay distances <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> and the lenses\u2019 angular diameter distances <em>D</em><sub>d</sub> provide some information on <em>w</em>, as the constraint contours are tilted rather than being vertical. With more lenses or smaller uncertainties on <em>D</em><sub>d</sub> measurements, the constraints on cosmology become more prominent (Jee et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). However, the H0LiCOW lenses provide strong cosmographic constraints when combined with the CMB measurements since they help to break parameter degeneracies in the CMB. Thus, we should be able to place substantially better constraints on, for example, the spatial curvature, <em>w</em> and <em>N</em><sub>eff</sub> (middle two columns), compared to constraints from CMB alone. In particular, we expect better than 3.5\u00a0per\u00a0cent precision on <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> for the two cosmologies with <em>w</em>\u00a0=\u00a0\u22121 (open \u039bCDM and flat <em>N</em><sub>eff</sub>\u039bCDM)<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn9\" data-open=\"fn9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>9</sup></a>; when <em>w</em> is allowed to vary, this constraint weakens to \u223c11\u2009per\u2009cent without CMB priors and \u223c5\u2009per\u2009cent with CMB priors in the <em>w</em>CDM cosmology, as visible in the rightmost panel in the middle row. By combining our five H0LiCOW lenses with <em>Planck</em>, we expect to achieve the following precisions: \u03a9<sub>k</sub> to 0.004 in open \u039bCDM, <em>w</em> to 0.14 in flat wCDM, and <em>N</em><sub>eff</sub> to 0.2 in flat <em>N</em><sub>eff</sub>\u039bCDM (all 1\u03c3 uncertainties). These precisions are a factor of \u223c15, \u223c2, and \u223c1.5, respectively, tighter than <em>Planck</em> on its own. Our H0LiCOW sample provides not only an independent check of systematics, but also a great complement to other cosmological probes for pinning down cosmological parameters.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=74112335 id=\"74112335\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7>7 SUMMARY AND OUTLOOK</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We present the H0LiCOW program that aims to measure <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> to &lt;3.5\u2009per\u2009cent in precision and accuracy (in most background cosmological models) with a sample of five time-delay lenses, completely independent of the cosmic distance ladder and other direct measurements of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>. Our cosmographic information comes from measuring the distances to the lens systems, specifically <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> and <em>D</em><sub>d</sub>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To achieve our goal, we have obtained almost all the key ingredients for our lens sample<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn10\" data-open=\"fn10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>10</sup></a>: (1) the time delays from the COSMOGRAIL and Very Large Array monitoring, (2) high-resolution <em>HST</em> imaging for modelling the lens mass distributions, (3) wide-field imaging and spectroscopy to quantify the effects of the lens environment, and (4) lens velocity dispersion measurements to augment our lensing mass models. Our new <em>HST</em> observations reveal Einstein rings in the lens systems that allow us to perform precision lens mass modelling.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The results of our recent blind analysis of HE\u00a00435\u22121223 will appear in the companion H0LiCOW publications. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib144\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib144\" data-open=\"bib144\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper II</a> (Sluse et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib144\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib144\" data-open=\"bib144\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) presents the spectroscopic campaign on the HE\u00a00435\u22121223 field and identifies galaxy groups in the light cone containing the lens. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib134\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib134\" data-open=\"bib134\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper III</a> (Rusu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib134\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib134\" data-open=\"bib134\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) combines the spectroscopy, the wide-field imaging data, and the Millennium Simulation to derive the external convergence of the line-of-sight mass distributions. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib187\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib187\" data-open=\"bib187\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper IV</a> (Wong et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib187\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib187\" data-open=\"bib187\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) models the lens mass distribution using the <em>HST</em> data, the time delays and the lens velocity dispersion to infer the time-delay distance, that is blinded throughout the analysis. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">H0LiCOW Paper V</a> (Bonvin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) presents the COSMOGRAIL monitoring of HE\u00a00435\u22121223 and investigates the cosmological implications based on the three lenses (B1608+656, RXJ1131\u22121231and HE\u00a00435\u22121223) that we have so far analysed.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">With our sample of five lenses, we expect to measure <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> to &lt;3.5\u2009per\u2009cent in precision and accuracy for the non-flat \u039bCDM cosmology or flat <em>N</em><sub>eff</sub>\u039bCDM cosmology, with <em>w</em>\u00a0=\u00a0\u22121. When <em>w</em> is allowed to vary, the constraint on <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> degrades to \u223c11\u2009per\u2009cent with time-delay data only, and to \u223c5\u2009per\u2009cent when augmented with CMB data. Our independent strong-lensing distances significantly improve cosmological constraints from the <em>Planck</em> data: the precisions on \u03a9<sub>k</sub>, <em>w</em>, and <em>N</em><sub>eff</sub> improve by a factor of \u223c15, \u223c2, and 1.5, respectively, when we combine our lenses with <em>Planck</em>. Time-delay lenses are therefore highly complementary to other cosmological probes.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our data set provides an excellent opportunity to study, in addition to cosmography, galaxy formation, and evolution. For example, we can study the distribution of dark matter in the lens galaxies by combining lensing and kinematics data, and also infer the stellar mass of the lens galaxies (e.g. Treu &amp; Koopmans\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib167\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib167\" data-open=\"bib167\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Barnab\u00e8 et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib147\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib147\" data-open=\"bib147\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib148\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib148\" data-open=\"bib148\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib159\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib159\" data-open=\"bib159\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012b</a>). By separately determining the stellar mass based on either (1) stellar population synthesis using multiband photometry (e.g. Auger et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Treu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib170\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib170\" data-open=\"bib170\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Oguri, Rusu &amp; Falco\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib111\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib111\" data-open=\"bib111\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), or (2) identification/characterization of spectral features (e.g. van Dokkum &amp; Conroy\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib173\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib173\" data-open=\"bib173\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Conroy &amp; van Dokkum\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Spiniello et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib150\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib150\" data-open=\"bib150\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib151\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib151\" data-open=\"bib151\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib152\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib152\" data-open=\"bib152\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Barnab\u00e8 et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), and comparing this stellar mass to that obtained from lensing and dynamics, we can study properties of the stellar population and infer the stellar IMF slope (e.g. Grillo et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Auger et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Treu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib170\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib170\" data-open=\"bib170\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Spiniello et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib149\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib149\" data-open=\"bib149\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib152\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib152\" data-open=\"bib152\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Barnab\u00e8 et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). There are about a dozen early-type lens galaxies that have been studied in detail for constraining the stellar IMF slope individually (e.g. Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib147\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib147\" data-open=\"bib147\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Barnab\u00e8 et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Spiniello et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib152\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib152\" data-open=\"bib152\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Newman et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib107\" data-open=\"bib107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), and these galaxies are all at redshifts below 0.35. Four of our H0LiCOW lens galaxies are at redshifts between 0.45 and 0.73, which would allow us to explore the stellar IMF with comparable precisions per lens galaxy as previous studies, but at substantially higher redshifts. Given the current tension in the IMF measurement between nearby (<em>z</em><sub>d</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.06) lens galaxies and <em>z</em><sub>d</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.2\u20130.3 lens galaxies (e.g. Smith &amp; Lucey\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib146\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib146\" data-open=\"bib146\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Newman et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib107\" data-open=\"bib107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), our H0LiCOW lenses would help assess whether the tensions are just limited to those particular objects or if they reflect a more general problem in our understanding of stellar populations. In addition, our lenses are natural telescopes that magnify the background sources, allowing us to study the host galaxies of the AGNs in detail and probe the origin of the co-evolution between supermassive black holes and their host galaxies (Peng et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib115\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib115\" data-open=\"bib115\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Rusu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib133\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib133\" data-open=\"bib133\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Ding et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our H0LiCOW program aims to establish gravitational lens time delays as an independent and competitive probe of cosmology, and paves the way for determining <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> to 1\u00a0per\u00a0cent in the future. Given the hundreds, if not thousands, of time-delay lens systems that are expected to be discovered in ongoing and future surveys such as the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (e.g. Oguri et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib110\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib110\" data-open=\"bib110\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Inada et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; More et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib99\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib99\" data-open=\"bib99\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016a</a>), the Dark Energy Survey (e.g. Agnello et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), the Hyper Suprime-Cam Survey (e.g. Chan et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), the Kilo-Degree Survey (e.g. Napolitano et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib106\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib106\" data-open=\"bib106\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), Euclid and the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (Oguri &amp; Marshall\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib109\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib109\" data-open=\"bib109\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), and continuous advances in high-resolution imaging and spectroscopy in the current and next generation of telescopes for observational follow-up (Linder\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Meng et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib95\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib95\" data-open=\"bib95\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), the H0LiCOW program will provide the basis for extracting cosmological information from the wealth of strong-lensing data sets. In particular, we expect the combination of facilities at different wavelengths such as the <em>HST</em> in the optical/near-IR, <em>James Webb Space Telescope</em> in the IR, large and extremely large telescopes with adaptive optics, the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array in the submillimetre waveband, and the Square Kilometer Array in the radio, will be of great synergistic value for studying these fruitful lenses.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=74112342 id=\"74112342\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" >Acknowledgments</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We thank M. Barnab\u00e8, J. Chan, Y. Hezaveh, E. Komatsu, E. Linder, J. McKean, D. Paraficz, P. Schneider and S. This work is based in part on observations and archival data obtained with the <em>Spitzer Space Telescope</em>, which is operated by the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology under a contract with NASA. This project used data obtained with the Dark Energy Camera (DECam), which was constructed by the Dark Energy Survey (DES) collaboration. Funding for the DES Projects has been provided by the U.S. Department of Energy, the U.S. National Science Foundation, the Ministry of Science and Education of Spain, the Science and Technology Facilities Council of the United Kingdom, the Higher Education Funding Council for England, the National Center for Supercomputing Applications at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, the Kavli Institute of Cosmological Physics at the University of Chicago, the Center for Cosmology and Astro-Particle Physics at the Ohio State University, the Mitchell Institute for Fundamental Physics and Astronomy at Texas A&amp;M University, Financiadora de Estudos e Projetos, Funda\u00e7\u00e3o Carlos Chagas Filho de Amparo \u00e0 Pesquisa do Estado do Rio de Janeiro, Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Cient\u00edfico e Tecnol\u00f3gico and the Minist\u00e9rio da Ci\u00eancia, Tecnologia e Inovac\u00e3o, the Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft and the Collaborating Institutions in the Dark Energy Survey. The Collaborating Institutions are Argonne National Laboratory, the University of California at Santa Cruz, the University of Cambridge, Centro de Investigaciones En\u00e9rgeticas, Medioambientales y Tecnol\u00f3gicas-Madrid, the University of Chicago, University College London, the DES-Brazil Consortium, the University of Edinburgh, the Eidgen\u00f6ssische Technische Hochschule (ETH) Z\u00fcrich, Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, the Institut de Ci\u00e8ncies de l'Espai (IEEC/CSIC), the Institut de F\u00edsica d'Altes Energies, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, the Ludwig-Maximilians Universit\u00e4t M\u00fcnchen and the associated Excellence Cluster Universe, the University of Michigan, the National Optical Astronomy Observatory, the University of Nottingham, the Ohio State University, the University of Pennsylvania, the University of Portsmouth, SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory, Stanford University, the University of Sussex and Texas A&amp;M University.</p><div content-id=\"fn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" class=\"end-note-link\">1</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">In terms of its impact on <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub>.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn2\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn2\" class=\"end-note-link\">2</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">The source redshift of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.654 is based on the narrow emission lines, which is considered more accurate than the H\u00a0\u03b1 and Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> lines (Hewett &amp; Wild\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) that yield <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.657 (Sluse et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib142\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib142\" data-open=\"bib142\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>). We note that a 0.003 change in <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> corresponds to a &lt;0.4\u2009per\u2009cent change in <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> for RXJ1131\u22121231, and even less change in <em>D</em><sub>\u0394<em>t</em></sub> for the other higher redshift lens systems.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn3\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn3\" class=\"end-note-link\">3</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Based on Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> emission line, which results in a slightly higher redshift value than the previous measurement of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.689 (Wisotzki et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib186\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib186\" data-open=\"bib186\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>) from C <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> line that is known to be prone to systematic blueshifts in many quasars.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn4\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn4\" class=\"end-note-link\">4</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">For HE\u00a00435\u22121223, one long exposure was lost due to a satellite passing over the target. For one of the parallelogram dither pattern for WFI2033\u22124723, we use an exposure sequence of short\u2013long (rather than short\u2013long\u2013long) at each dither position to optimize target exposure time given overhead associated with observations.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn5\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn5\" class=\"end-note-link\">5</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><span class=\"small-caps\">DrizzlePac</span> is a product of the Space Telescope Science Institute, which is operated by AURA for NASA.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn6\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn6\" class=\"end-note-link\">6</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">A lens modelling software package developed by A. Halkola and S. H. Suyu (Suyu &amp; Halkola <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib155\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib155\" data-open=\"bib155\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib159\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib159\" data-open=\"bib159\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012b</a>).</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn7\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn7\" class=\"end-note-link\">7</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">The flexion shift corresponds to the shift in the image positions due to the flexion (third-order derivatives of the lens potential) of a line-of-sight perturber. McCully et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) find through their study of simulated lens fields that perturbers with flexion shifts larger than \u223c10<sup>\u22124</sup> arcsec should be incorporated explicitly in the multiplane lens mass model. The threshold of \u223c10<sup>\u22124</sup> arcsec is conservative and is based on tests that only used image positions as constraints. It may be that using the spatially extended images for modelling would push that threshold even lower.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn8\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn8\" class=\"end-note-link\">8</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">We use the <em>Planck</em> chains designated by \u2018plikHM_TT_lowTEB\u2019 that uses the baseline high-L <em>Planck</em> power spectra and low-L temperature and LFI polarization.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn9\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn9\" class=\"end-note-link\">9</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Relative to <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = 72\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u2212 1</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u2212 1</sup>.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn10\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn10\" class=\"end-note-link\">10</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">With spectroscopic observations of HE\u00a01104\u22121805 pending for lens velocity dispersion measurement.</p></div></span></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=74112355 id=\"74112355\" Abbreviations are LRIS (Low-Resolution Imaging Spectrometer; Oke et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib112\"></span>1995; Rockosi et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib129\"></span>2010), ESI (Echellete Spectrograph and Imager; Sheinis et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib139\"></span>2002), VLT (Very Large Telescope), FORS2 (FOcal Reducer and low dispersion Spectrograph; Appenzeller et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span>1998) and GMOS (Gemini Multi-Object Spectrographs; Hook et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span>2004). Details of the observations for B1608+656 are in Fassnacht et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span>2006), and for the other four lenses are in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib144\"></span>H0LiCOW Paper II and forthcoming publications. Additional integral field spectroscopy of the central 30 arcmin around WFI2033\u22124723 has been recently obtained with the Multi Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE; Bacon et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span>2012) on the VLT.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/[XSLTSectionID][QueryString]\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Wide-field spectroscopy of H0LiCOW lenses as part of the H0LiCOW program.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Lens<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Facility/instrument<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Proposal PI<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>B1608+656\u00a0</td><td>W. Abbreviations are LRIS (Low-Resolution Imaging Spectrometer; Oke et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib112\"></span>1995; Rockosi et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib129\"></span>2010), ESI (Echellete Spectrograph and Imager; Sheinis et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib139\"></span>2002), VLT (Very Large Telescope), FORS2 (FOcal Reducer and low dispersion Spectrograph; Appenzeller et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span>1998) and GMOS (Gemini Multi-Object Spectrographs; Hook et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span>2004). Details of the observations for B1608+656 are in Fassnacht et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span>2006), and for the other four lenses are in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib144\"></span>H0LiCOW Paper II and forthcoming publications. Additional integral field spectroscopy of the central 30 arcmin around WFI2033\u22124723 has been recently obtained with the Multi Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE; Bacon et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span>2012) on the VLT.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/[XSLTSectionID][QueryString]\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div> \n    </div>\n\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n    <div Rusu\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>VLT/HAWK-I\u00a0</td><td><em>J, H, K</em>\u00a0</td><td>C. D. Fassnacht\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>HE\u00a01104\u22121805\u00a0</td><td>CFHT/MegaCam\u00a0</td><td><em>u</em>\u00a0</td><td>S. H. Fassnacht\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>Gemini/NIRI\u00a0</td><td><em>J, <em>K</em><sub>s</sub></em>\u00a0</td><td>C. D. Fassnacht\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN003\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN003\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>. Abbreviations and references for the instruments are CFHT (Canada\u2013France\u2013Hawaii Telescope) MegaCam (Boulade et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span>2003), Suprime-Cam (Miyazaki et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib96\"></span>2002), MOIRCS (Multi-Object InfraRed Camera and Spectrograph; Suzuki et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib162\"></span>2008; Ichikawa et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span>2006), NIRI (Near InfraRed Imager and Spectrometer; Hodapp et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span>2003), IRAC (Infrared Array Camera; Fazio et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span>2004), CTIO (Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory) DECam (Dark Energy Camera; Diehl &amp; Dark Energy Survey Collaboration\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span>2012), VLT (Very Large Telescope) HAWK-I (High Acuity Wide field K-band Imager; Pirard et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib118\"></span>2004; Casali et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span>2006; Kissler-Patig et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span>2008). Details of the observations are in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib134\"></span>H0LiCOW Paper III and forthcoming publications. WFI2033\u22124723 is in the footprint of the Dark Energy Survey with observations in <em>g</em>, <em>r</em>, <em>i</em>, <em>z</em> and <em>Y</em> bands, so we did not target WFI2033\u22124723 in these bands. We observed only B1608+656 with <em>Spitzer</em> since the other four lenses have archival <em>Spitzer</em>/IRAC observations (PI: C. S. Kochanek).</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/[XSLTSectionID][QueryString]\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Wide-field imaging obtained as part of the H0LiCOW program.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Lens<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Facility/instrument<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Wavelength bands<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Proposal PI<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>B1608+656\u00a0</td><td>CFHT/MegaCam\u00a0</td><td><em>u</em>\u00a0</td><td>S. src=\"//cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/mathjax/2.7.1/MathJax.js?config=TeX-AMS-MML_HTMLorMML\"></script>\r\n\r\n\r\n<script src=\"//cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/promise-polyfill@8/dist/polyfill.min.js\"></script>\r\n\r\n    <script type=\"text/javascript\" src=\"//oup.silverchair-cdn.com/UI/versioned-asset/637439192420341521/UI/app/jsdist/footer.min.js\"></script>\r\n    <script async=\"async\" src=\"//s7.addthis.com/js/300/addthis_widget.js#pubid=xa-5265518246c10183&domready=1\"></script>\r\n\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n    <!-- Copyright 2001-2010, IBM Corporation All rights reserved. -->\r\n    <script src=\"//ouptag.scholarlyiq.com/ntpagetag.js\"></script>\r\n    <noscript>\r\n        <img src=\"//ouptag.scholarlyiq.com/ntpagetag.gif?js=0\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" border=\"0\" hspace=\"0\" vspace=\"0\" alt=\"Scholarly IQ\" />\r\n    </noscript>\r\n\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"ad-banner js-ad-riser ad-banner-riser\">\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-AdBlock widget-instance-RiserAd\">\n         \n    </div>\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n\r\n</body>\r\n</html>\r\n\r\n", "Status": "Skipped", "Link": "https://academic.oup.com/view-large/74112309", "Table captions or footers": {"Overview": ">For full access to this pdf, sign in to an existing account, or purchase an annual subscription."}}}, "Paper Overview": {"authors": ["Suyu, S. H.", "Bonvin, V.", "Courbin, F.", "Fassnacht, C. D.", "Rusu, C. E.", "Sluse, D.", "Treu, T.", "Wong, K. C.", "Auger, M. W.", "Ding, X.", "Hilbert, S.", "Marshall, P. J.", "Rumbaugh, N.", "Sonnenfeld, A.", "Tewes, M.", "Tihhonova, O.", "Agnello, A.", "Blandford, R. D.", "Chen, G. C. -F.", "Collett, T.", "Koopmans, L. V. E.", "Liao, K.", "Meylan, G.", "Spiniello, C."], "journal_name": "Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society", "type_of_reference": "JOUR", "abstract": "Strong gravitational lens systems with time delays between the multiple images allow measurements of time-delay distances, which are primarily sensitive to the Hubble constant that is key to probing dark energy, neutrino physics and the spatial curvature of the Universe, as well as discovering new physics. We present H0LiCOW (H<SUB>0</SUB> Lenses in COSMOGRAIL's Wellspring), a program that aims to measure H<SUB>0</SUB> with &lt;3.5 per cent uncertainty from five lens systems (B1608+656, RXJ1131-1231, HE 0435-1223, WFI2033-4723 and HE 1104-1805). We have been acquiring (1) time delays through COSMOGRAIL and Very Large Array monitoring, (2) high-resolution Hubble Space Telescope imaging for the lens mass modelling, (3) wide-field imaging and spectroscopy to characterize the lens environment and (4) moderate-resolution spectroscopy to obtain the stellar velocity dispersion of the lenses for mass modelling. In cosmological models with one-parameter extension to flat \u039b cold dark matter, we expect to measure H<SUB>0</SUB> to &lt;3.5 per cent in most models, spatial curvature \u03a9<SUB>k</SUB> to 0.004, w to 0.14 and the effective number of neutrino species to 0.2 (1\u03c3 uncertainties) when combined with current cosmic microwave background (CMB) experiments. These are, respectively, a factor of \u223c15, \u223c2 and \u223c1.5 tighter than CMB alone. Our data set will further enable us to study the stellar initial mass function of the lens galaxies, and the co-evolution of supermassive black holes and their host galaxies. This program will provide a foundation for extracting cosmological distances from the hundreds of time-delay lenses that are expected to be discovered in current and future surveys.", "doi": "10.1093/mnras/stx483", "start_page": "2590", "number": "3", "publication_year": "2017/07/1", "end_page": "2604", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:1607.00017", "author_address": ["AA(Max-Planck-Institut f\u00fcr Astrophysik, Karl-Schwarzschild-Str. 1, D-85748 Garching, Germany;
